Tarkan Al-Kazily1:59 PM

I definitely can make that happen! I imagine you’ll want to see the computer vision component that we’ve been working on, so I’ll have to see about what we can run, but I’m confident I can make this happen under pretty short notice. We actually have two groups working under ARUW, and I believe Shamal was part of the second group.

Tarkan Al-Kazily2:01 PM

The main ARUW team is more akin to FIRST robotics, where we are building our own robots from scratch. The robot you saw with Shamal was supplied by DJI, and Shamal’s team was working on developing a pathfinding ai component for it. I can contact the leads on that group to see when is best for them to show of their tech, if you’d like.

Tarkan Al-Kazily2:11 PM

I’m able to give a tour pretty much any day of the week. The busier days are usually Monday through Wednesday, but I imagine that you’ll likely come in around 4 - 5 for the tour, which should be a good time any day of the week, as people will be starting to gather to get to work. Note that most of our robotics work now is still in the mechanical phase, but we’ve got a bunch of groups developing on the main control boards for the robots. The CV component is mostly finalized, and is waiting for integration.

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:06 PM

For teaching new programmers next year, this[1] paper evaluates many coding tutorials in a helpful way (the diagram on page 3 is great.) We need a good take-home resource for learning the basics (of Java), and I think this can help with finding such a resource.
[1]: https://faculty.washington.edu/ajko/papers/Kim2017CodingTutorialEvaluation.pdf>

Ronan Bennett7:27 PM

2018-05-02
Darwin Clark8:54 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason Looking at the GradleRIO github, it appears they have support for coprocessors, do you think this is something worthwhile to look into?

Darwin Clark8:54 PM

This could be something to use for the PI next year, however they don't have examples in Python

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:16 PM

I have looked in to the GradleRIO coprocessor support, and I think that it's a useful automation to evaluate if more than one person is seriously working on vision and if deploy times are fast. At the same time, SSH to the Pi is fast and easy once you get the hang of it (it seems), so we shouldn't fix what isn't broken. If you have the time, I would look into it.

I have typed exclusively on my nice, quiet, high-quality Lenovo laptop keyboard for years, and I must say I do miss the clickety clackety of the old school keyboards sometimes. Maybe it's a musician thing - fast-typing surges and subsequent slowdowns (maybe when pondering what to type) are akin to crescendos and decrescendos, and there is something enjoyable about hearing it...

2018-05-25
Chris Rininger5:57 PM

I was just reading this interesting thread on how teams approach drivetrains powered by 775pro motors. People talk about things like...
- Four 775pro motors on each side (one gearbox per side)
- Using one Talon SRX on one motor and three Victor SPXs on the other motors per gearbox for voltage control. Evidently around 40 amps works well for protecting the motors.
- Someone mentioned "CTRE makes these easy for any FRC team to use now" in connection with the above

Is this something our team understands? If not, even if we will stick with a 4 CIM single speed drivetrain, it seems like this might be good stuff to learn if we want to be able to "overpower" mechanisms with multiple 775pro motors into a single gearbox, while protecting the motors from burning up.

Here's the thread: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/forums/showthread.php?threadid=165562>

2018-05-26
Declan Freeman-Gleason3:48 PM

Yes, the team understands "CTRE makes these easy". With the right motor controllers (especially Talons) you have many knobs you can tweak.

Declan Freeman-Gleason3:52 PM

What are the advantages to this approach? I couldn't really see any when reading this thread (people where mentioning empirical performance measurements that I have no reference for, which could be the problem.) Is this good for a custom chassis? What are we fixing with this approach (we've never had motor burnouts in my time on the team.)

Chris Rininger11:31 PM

CIM motors are powerful and hard to burn out because they can stall for a pretty long time, but they're heavy at 2.8 lbs (due to the case). 775pro (& Redline) motors are similarly powerful, though they spin 3 times as fast and thus require different gearing for the same task. The main advantage of 775pros over CIMs is weight (they're 0.8 lbs.), and the main disadvantage is they burn out almost immediately if stalled (like during a pushing match if used on a drive train), and they can also burn out if just overworked for too long. For any task requiring a lot of power and that does not involve the risk of stalling or sustained load, a 775pro makes sense. For tasks requiring power & that DO involve a risk of stalling or sustained load, the safe way to go is a CIM. The people on the thread are talking about having cake and eating it by using multiple 775pros into a single transmission (overpower) and then using the Talon SRX and multiple slaved Victor SPX to limit current as a mitigation to the risk of burning out the motor.

I brought it up because one of the things we have talked about is having overpowered mechanims (for extra speed, for example). It seems like one way teams are doing that is multiple 775pro motors into a single transmission with controllers as described in the thread. For example, lots of teams used two or three 775pro motors with their elevators this year, and my guess is most of those teams used a set up like this.

2018-12-10
Dana Batali5:00 PM

thread for Spartronics-254Base2018/Drive

Dana Batali5:01 PM

Drive.java has several hardcoded 4096 in readPeriodicInputs. These should all be converted to use `Constants.kDriveEncoderPPR` which for us should be set to (360*4)

cf: `radiansPerSecondToTicksPer100ms()` and `readPeriodicInputs()`

Dana Batali5:15 PM

docs on voltage compensation (nice to find more on this):

"This is the voltage that the motor controller will compensate "full" output to. For example, if 10V is configured for the saturation point, when the motor controller is commanded 50%, it will modulate until the output is 5V. This applies to closed-loop modes as well."

Dana Batali5:17 PM

so in theory, we could tune our pids as though our battery was producing 10V (it produces a nominal 12V) and the software will compensate a 50% power request according to the current state of the battery. 254 enables this capability and selects 12V as the "saturation" point.

2018-12-11
Dana Batali11:37 AM

Spartronics 2018 standard drive wiring:

• kLeftNormalRightInverted - means the left motor runs in "normal" mode, while the right motor runs inverted (positive voltages mean reversed rotation)
• configSensorPhase was set to the same sense as the inverted - ie: left set to "false", right set to "true". Here's the help text:

Sets the phase of the sensor. Use when controller forward/reverse output doesn't correlate to appropriate forward/reverse reading of sensor. Pick a value so that positive PercentOutput yields a positive change in sensor. After setting this, user can freely call SetInvert() with any value.

Dana Batali12:15 PM

great video on frc vision:
http://imjac.in/ta/post/2017/11/18/computer-vision-scratching-the-surface.html>

Dana Batali2:17 PM

when running in pathfollowing mode (ie: auto), Drive.updatePathFollower() is invoked via looper. This causes mMotionPlanner to produce a suggested drive output given current RobotState estimate. The output velocity is written to its PeriodicOutputs. These values are only sent to the motors when the SystemManager later invokes Drive.writePeriodicOutputs():


mLeftMaster.set(ControlMode.Velocity,
mPeriodicIO.leftdemand,
DemandType.ArbitraryFeedForward,
mPeriodicIO.leftfeedforward,
Constants.kDriveVelocityKd * mPeriodicIO.leftaccel / 1023.0);
...


this unfamiliar variant of the `set` method supports a secondary demand value that is combined with the primary demand according the the demandType_. For AbitraryFeedForward:


ArbitraryFeedForward: Use demand1 as an arbitrary additive value to the demand0 output. In PercentOutput the demand0 output is the motor output and in closed-loop modes the demand0 output is the output of PID0.

Not clear what value this additional control over the PID represents.

Dana Batali2:50 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: please let me know how you'd like to proceed on migrating the 254 code into our conventions. Specifically: did you commit the changes we were making on Sunday?

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:51 PM

I did commit Sunday's changes

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:52 PM

There are some things commented out that should be fixed when we get the Pigeon (I have already picked up the cables).

Dana Batali2:57 PM

can you remind me which line/constant we miscommunicated on that produced the bogus brownout behavior ("bbb")?

Dana Batali2:58 PM

i think it may have been a feedforward constant

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:41 PM

http://www.ctr-electronics.com/downloads/api/java/html/com/ctre/phoenix/motorcontrol/can/BaseMotorController.html#set-com.ctre.phoenix.motorcontrol.ControlMode-double-com.ctre.phoenix.motorcontrol.DemandType-double->

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:42 PM

The `DemandType` we're using is `ArbitraryFeedforward`.

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:48 PM

As you can see on line 350 of the linked file, this "arbitrary feedforward" is being generated by our drivetrain model and then adjusted by the controller of our choice (feedforward doesn't change the model's output, of course).

https://github.com/Spartronics4915/Spartronics-254Base2018/blob/master/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/frc2019/planners/DriveMotionPlanner.java>

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:55 AM

1. Check path in webapp
2. Manually enter waypoints into `TrajectoryGenerator`

(`TrajectoryGenerator` before I stripped out all the old paths is a good example of how things should work).

I think it all depends on how inconvenient it is for you to transport the chassis.

Interestingly, I can deploy when this line is not commented out, when I deploy from the command line (but not from the webapp).

2018-12-18

2018-12-19
Declan Freeman-Gleason6:46 PM

Thread on Spartronics-254Base2018 LIDAR

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:16 PM

@Dana Batali I looked over the changes... They look pretty good. A few comments:
1. (Nitpick) I don't really like where `LidarMain` is placed (it's not really a library, and it's not consistient with where the path webapp is). I'm going to go ahead and refactor this to be more consistient with the path webapp's placement, if you're alright with that.
2. We're now mixing `System.currentTimeMillis` and `Timer.getFPGATimestamp` in some places. It seems like this won't work unless we convert all our timer usages to one or the other (the two timers have different epochs). We can't convert all uses to `Timer.getFPGATimestamp`, because that wouldn't work with our off-robot test. That leaves us with either converting everything to `System.currentTimeMillis`, or doing something clever to switch between the two, like making a timer interface and a wrapper for `System.currentTimeMillis`.
3. I fixed a couple of absolute ICP bugs in my fork of LidarDEV, so I'm going to go ahead and port them to the mainline.

Thanks!

Dana Batali9:17 PM

I think the important thing is that code under frc201x is okay to depend on wpilib. lib is one way to say that this code doesn't have that dependency. I would suggest that lidarapp makes as much sense under lib.lidar as anywhere and probably better than http://lib.app|lib.app>. On a related topic I notice that all the java web app stuff appears in the jar we download to the robot. Does that make sense?

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:53 PM

I see what you mean with lib... On the other hand, I think it's important to indicate that you couldn't use LidarMain as a standalone library. We also have the path webapp stuff outside of lib. In this case, I think that code under lib not being used as a library is more surprising than the alternative, so I'm going to go with the alternative.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:56 PM

I think we definitely don't want the web app stuff in the robot code... I'll take a look around to see how we can avoid this.

Dana Batali10:44 PM

Hmm as I understand in any java class can include a static main. It doesnt imply anything other than it could be used as a standalone app. If we already have a place for lidar code doesn't it make sense for it all to be together? Not sure I agree the the word library implies that one can't make an app of a library component... But you're right we're getting into the weeds here

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:48 PM

It does, but there's something to be said for maintaining consistiency with the way we do it for the other "standalone" part of the code that uses `lib` (the webapp)...

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:54 PM

Here are my changes: https://github.com/Spartronics4915/Spartronics-254Base2018/pull/1>

Let me know how you feel about the refactoring after you take a look. If you still prefer keeping things in `lib`, then I'll go ahead and move them back there.

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:40 PM

Also, is it a mistake that we're instantiating a `LidarProcessor` in both `RobotStateEstimator` and `Robot`? I would think that we would only want to have `LidarProcessor` in `RobotStateEstimator`, so we could feed our states into the state map.

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:41 PM

What's your plan with IRobotStateMap? I see you only have one implementer right now. Did you intend to make `LidarMain` and implementer too, or was it something else?

2018-12-20
Dana Batali10:03 AM

seems like we could/should migrate RobotStateMap from frc* to lib/util or lib/geometry (again, lib is code that can operate without wpilibs). As you surmised, my focus was mostly to get the two code bases to co-habitate and I wasn't really focused on the final wiring in of the lidar results into the robot state. This is still "to do". Finally, you're right the LidarProcessor in Robot.java was vestigial. Good catch! (i checked in that fix).

Declan Freeman-Gleason6:41 PM

Ha! I found it! This bug was causing hangs, no-starts, and processing "sluggishness": https://github.com/Spartronics4915/Spartronics-254Base2018/commit/facbdadf3ff3d4ecc3a2ccead3b5ac6ebc456e24#diff-da92eff1cd22bb817440b04acd46efa4R182>

2018-12-21
Dana Batali2:26 PM

:+1:

Dana Batali5:33 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason - today i tried to get chezylidar running on the roborio and ran into a couple roadbumps. Perhaps you can help research the issue. Long story short: chezylidar works when run as admin, but not as lvuser. The key driver file is referenced as: /dev/serial/by-id/blah-UART-blah... This turns out to be a symlink to /dev/ttyUSB0


lrwxrwxrwx 1 admin administ 13 Dec 31 1969 usb-SiliconLabsCP2102USBtoUARTBridgeController0001-if00-port0 -> ../../ttyUSB0



and here's the perms for /dev/USB0:


crw-rw-rw- 1 admin tty 188, 0 Dec 3 17:07 ttyUSB0
l

Dana Batali5:34 PM

i note that lvuser is a member of tty grou. I also tried adding lvuser to the administrator group and that didn't solve the problem.

Dana Batali5:35 PM

(i ran into a similar issue on macos, but roborio had a different behavior)

Dana Batali7:19 PM

btw: I don’t actually know whether robot code runs as root... if it does 1) it would be sad 2) it would solve the problem

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:42 PM

I had to add myself to the `dialout` group (I forgot I even did this up until now)... I don't know if this will work on the RoboRIO though. https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/14354/read-write-to-a-serial-port-without-root>

Dana Batali8:47 PM

i think the tty group is analogous to the dialout group... I'll give it a go tomorrow with fingers crossed

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:10 PM

Design question on `IRobotStateMap`:
Currently we have a `get` method. Do we also want a `put` method? (Yes we do, I think. That sentiment doesn't address how we're going to fuse pose information from LIDAR though.) Do you think it makes sense to replace some of the other methods in `frc2018.RobotState` with `getState`? What do you think a good way to deal with predicted velocity is (should we just add another field to `State`)?

Dana Batali10:25 PM

We could literally eliminate the interface and move RobstStateMap to libs (it’s just a tree map of interpolatabke pose2d... I’m not near code right now (waiting at airport)... but i recall thinking that we should store measured velocity in the map (did I generalize pose2d plus measured velocity already?)

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:13 PM

It looks like one of `State`'s fields is `velocity`. Right now we don't store measured velocity in the map, which means that `RobotState` doesn't really "correctly" implement the interface (it always returns the current velocity regardless of the requested timestamp).

Dana Batali11:21 PM

Agreed... seems fairly low risk to store the ‘entire’ RobotState (pose2d plus velocity plus more?) in the map

Dana Batali11:22 PM

Perhaps that’s the same as pose2d plus twist2d?

2018-12-22
Declan Freeman-Gleason12:43 PM

I'm not sure I follow... Which `Pose2d` and `Twist2d`?

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:45 PM

We could also get rid of the entire `State` class, and just add more methods to the `IRobotStateMap` method. (Or we add everything to `State` and get rid of the other methods. Either way, I would prefer to have one canonical entrypoint to get velocity/position/whatever else. Right now there are two ways.)

Dana Batali1:22 PM

now I'm not sure i follow... IRobotStateMap.State represents the RobotState that we'd like to look in the past. So we do need a concise representation for that. Initially it was just a Pose2d, but if we want to do Lidar Odometry, i think it may help to have both a Pose2d and a Twist2d (which is analogous to x and deltax). In the concrete implementation of RobotState, there are a couple of frc dependencies that might need to be factored out... 1) smartdashboard calls and 2) direct communication with drive (to reset the gyro).

Can you be more specific about what you mean by two ways to access robot setate?

Dana Batali1:25 PM

right now, the method:

public synchronized IRobotStateMap.State get(double timestamp)

accesses the map for the pose and looks up the most recent `vehiclevelocitypredicted`. Above, i mused that it may make sense to store the current measured velocity with the pose2d.

Thus:

`InterpolatingTreeMap<InterpolatingDouble, Pose2d> fieldtovehicle`

would become:

`InterpolatingTreeMap<InterpolatingDouble, State> fieldtovehicle_`

Declan Freeman-Gleason1:31 PM

Oh, when you said plus you meant defining State as `{ Pose2d pose, Twist2d velocity, Twist2d predictedVelocity }`. I thought you meant addition...

Declan Freeman-Gleason1:33 PM

Anyway, when I said there are two ways I meant that to get the current pose you can do:
`get().position`, or `getLatestFieldToVehicle()`.

Dana Batali1:40 PM

i'm not sure if we need to store predictedVelocity and measuredVelocity in our Map, but it might not hurt. As for getLastestFieldToVehicle and getFieldToVehicle, these can be re-implemented in terms of get(), but i see no problem of these as convenience methods.

But back to the refactoring problem: if your goal is to make LidarTest operational on non-robot (ie: desktop), then it doesn't seem too hard to just migrate the file as is (with some refactoring to rest your concerns) and abstract out the drive and dashboard.

Declan Freeman-Gleason1:45 PM

I think we might only want to have one way to get this information. That could mean a wholesale migration of `RobotState` and removal of `IRobotStateMap`, or removal of `getLatestFieldToVehicle()` and friends (this would require refactoring/touching of a lot of other code).

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:20 PM

@Dana Batali Would it be bad to change `IRobotStateMap` to something like this?

package com.spartronics4915.lib.geometry;

public interface IRobotStateMap
{
public Pose2d getFieldToVehicle(double timestamp);
public Twist2d getMeasuredVelocity();
}

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:26 PM

We could probably even avoid including `getMeasuredVelocity`, right?

Dana Batali2:36 PM

i don't think it's right to get rid of velocity. That's part of the whole point here in my mind. IE: we want more than just Pose2d at an arbitrary point in time in order to produce Lidar-based odometry. Position and Velocity are "atomic" meaning that we want Pose2d and Twist2d at the same instant in the past (which might be interpolated). So this is why I introduced RobotStateMap::State. The additional work to make it sing would be to make RobotStateMap::State an interpolable (Pose2d is already interpolable) then store the entire state into our map. Now to make all the old stuff work, we can express the old methods (getFieldToVehicle(timestamp), getLatestFieldToVehicle) as calls to the all-powerful get(timestamp) (perhaps timestamp of -1 would equate to "latest").

Dana Batali2:37 PM

(kinda feels like we'd be more efficient to discuss this rather than type elliptically like I seem to always succeed in doing) :wink:

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:37 PM

That's probably true

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:37 PM

I considered making it interpolable

Dana Batali2:38 PM

it would have to be in order to live in our InterpolatingTreeMap

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:38 PM

But if we never need past velocity, we might consider just sculpting the interface around what they already have

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:39 PM

E.g.:

package com.spartronics4915.lib.geometry;

public interface IRobotStateMap
{
public Pose2d getFieldToVehicle(double timestamp);
public Pose2d getFieldToLidar(double timestamp);
public Twist2d getMeasuredVelocity();
}

Dana Batali2:39 PM

if lidar time smearing problems is on our plate, then i think we want velocity in the past

Dana Batali2:41 PM

and you've already mentioned the need for a method: addObservations.

Dana Batali2:41 PM

(which is sorta why i favor migrating the entire RoboState class under libs and eliminating frc* dependencies.

Dana Batali2:42 PM

and at this point we really don't need an interface and could just share the same class between robot and LidarTest

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:42 PM

That sounds about right...

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:57 PM

I think I know how to do this. PR should appear in a while.

Declan Freeman-Gleason6:39 PM

2018-12-26
Declan Freeman-Gleason5:02 PM

@Dana Batali Some thoughts on where we are right now:

1. The robot is our main blocker at this point. LIDAR-based localization's viability can only be further established by actually running it on the robot. Path planning is in a similar place (it can only be debugged and tuned on-robot). I propose that I take the robot home after we meet: I think that's the only way to get enough time with it (unless we want to meet for like 3 days). That plan would probably also require borrowing @Riyadth Al-Kazily's battery charger (I don't think the batteries we have will last).
2. With that in mind, here's were I think our priorities stand:
a. Path planning
b. Vision (We know this is going to be viable in 2019, because of the scotchlite announcement; I've gotten @Darwin Clark working on this, and we're going to meet on the 28th to discuss it).
c. LIDAR (We need to establish how effective this is, but I think it's actually last priority regardless of efficacy. I think that we should make sure there are no major bugs, and then table LIDAR until kickoff when we know if we should pursue it further).

Let me know what you think, and what day you want to meet. (Tomorrow?)

Dana Batali5:11 PM

Dana Batali11:38 AM

couple questions:

1. jerkiness during auto - you mean for the 2 foot straight? Here our challenge was to determine which constants control max velocity. Perhaps your last-most change to that value just kicked in?

2. icp in relative. As we discussed there are some issues we need to resolve there, in particular getting a velocity estimate that doesn't depend on wheel odometry or field coords. There may be another coord-sys issue there too (like the 0 in the y coord?)

3. i recall the current prioritization for your time was to get deeper into path planning. To learn more about the various physics constants etc. Overlapping this is the idea of characterizing each drivetrain side with the Ks, Kv, Ka values. If you remember all this confusing mish-mash differently please update me with your sense of priorities. (ie: i'm confused that you're working on lidar when I had the sense that you'd be working on pathplanning).

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:59 PM

Jerkiness persisted after I brought the robot home, but then it inexplicably started working (not after a `./gradlew deploy`.

I checked in what I think a fix for this might be… I’ll make a PR so you can take a look. Even if velocity math is wrong, this shouldn’t affect the pose part of relative LIDAR odometry.

Path planning is the first priority, but I wanted to establish (roughly) how effective LIDAR is before kickoff… I also had finished everything I could where I had the robot last night, so the only other thing I could do was try out the LIDAR. It’s mostly path planning from here.

2018-12-29
Declan Freeman-Gleason9:23 PM

@Dana Batali Notes from my time with the robot today:
1. Jerky behavior that sometimes went away was caused by selecting the wrong PID slot... You can see the fix in this commit: https://github.com/pietroglyph/Spartronics-254Base2018/commit/33f7024b757527d3f52d8623584267ea7bd814f9#diff-e2f1bcb3282c85729f7dfc63c70dbb6bL265>
2. I characterized both sides... The results are attached, and they really don't paint a picture where the two sides are very different.
3. Feedfoward from solving forward dynamics using our characterization and the other physics constants produces a feedforward that overshoots our target (and has some other odd behavior). This is the most pressing area.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:31 PM

Darwin Clark9:10 PM

@Dana Batali I spent some time tonight installing the Raspberry Pi WpiLIB vision image. To me it seems like a no-brainer for us to switch. The image has significant of features compared to vanilla raspibin. To name just a few: easily-configuarable read-only system from web dashboard, system diagnostics from web dashboard (Including network!) , and camera viewing tool. However, I'm currently skeptical about the integration with our existing code. (aforementioned utilities seems to be configured for USB cams exclusively) Over the next few days I'm going to dig deeper in regard to compatibility. Thoughts?

Chris Rininger9:35 PM

CD thread on line tracing. Discussion includes researching 2011 (very similar tape on floor), using three line sensors together, using a pixycam plus there are links to a couple other threads including one from the mentioned 2011 year. https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/lining-up-with-tape-on-ground-for-new-game/338591/2>

2019-01-08
Dana Batali11:13 AM

Great that you've already been looking at this! I agree that it would be worth going for as long as:

• we can program it with python (and javascript/nodejs?)
• we can plug in a raspi camera (non-usb). I would guess that it's as simple as manually updating the python distro with the raspi camera package. Remember: we haven't yet found a affordable usb camera that delivers > 30 fps. (the raspi cam can get to 90fps and gives us more control over quality, exposure, etc).
• it supports multiple, switchable camera feeds
• we can integrate feedback & camera views into our smartdashboard
• we can measure/minimize any overhead associated with their management and web services
• we can programatically govern the bandwidth consumption associated with multiple cameras. In prior years smartdashboard controls allowed us to change camera view - and since we pulled data to the driver station we only paid for the bandwidth the driver requested.

Dana Batali11:19 AM

What this package seems to offer us that we hadn't yet developed:

1. config for read-only filesystem (which theoretically makes it more robust to brownout, etc)
2. gui for system diagnostics

If we have problems integrating these things into our smartdashboard on the driver station, we can certainly obtain these capabilities without the turnkey package.

Dana Batali11:21 AM

@Darwin Clark: can you give me a sense of whether these aspects are all "just doable"? Another way to make the decision: what are the things we get for free compared to the things we'd have to give up.

Dana Batali12:23 PM

regarding video, latency, etc:
we currently use opencv with python with a raspi camera (not usb, so faster) to produce jpg frames that are streamed to the client via a streaming mjpg server. We could theoretically reduce latency by bypassing the mjpg streaming server through the use of websockets or webrtc. The latter is an api that doesn't appear to have python bindings. It does have a javascript binding and, coupled with the javascript binding to opencv might let us have our cake and eat it too.

https://github.com/sandeepmistry/node-raspberry-pi-camera-native>

https://github.com/justadudewhohacks/opencv4nodejs>

https://github.com/shanet/WebRTC-Example>

https://github.com/waveform80/pistreaming>

Dana Batali1:29 PM

also: i've unearthed some interesting findings in the vision thread. Questions implied:

does the frc-pi system include node.js and the javascript bindings to opencv?

2019-01-09
Darwin Clark11:11 AM

Sorry I have't responded until now...Based on the work I've done, I'm unsure if we can program it with JavaScript, but usability with our picam definitely seems to exist. To use our script, it seems a simple matter of configuration on the web dashboard (Which is a fairly easy to navigate UI, I can run through it with you in person if you like; for now I'm going to hand-wave specifics). On the subject of switchable camera feeds: Their support of multiple cameras is based off of a python script which only operates with USB cameras, however based on the reading I've done on CD, IP cameras seem to be the go-to choice for teams (For driver vision). I don't think it's likely we are going to be using the Pi for anything other than vision processing. I have not yet deployed our vision code to the pi yet, that's next on my agenda. (as a proof of concept)

2019-01-10
Dana Batali11:35 AM

fwiw: we've tried the standard axis IP camera and found that it suffered from latency problems. Also the axis is, iirc, approximately the cost of 3 raspberry picam setups. That led us to try the cheaper dlink we've used in the past. We tweaked it to low-quality settings and according to drivers was still too high-latency.

Dana Batali3:09 PM

https://all3dp.com/raspberry-pi-camera-cases-mounts/>

2019-01-11
Declan Freeman-Gleason10:32 AM

This paper is titled "Implementation of Adaptive Pure Pursuit Controllers", but it actually also goes into dynamic generation of feedforward terms (they have an interesting tuning strategy relavant to use on page 17), odometry, and driving in arcs (e.g. what is a `Twist2d`). https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/paper-implementation-of-the-adaptive-pure-pursuit-controller/166552>

Declan Freeman-Gleason4:46 PM

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1X_pzTDPp-EWDG9Qyb5i7y4Glz9iZBpMzXzntQhuP47U>

2019-01-12
Declan Freeman-Gleason5:18 PM

It describes measuring camera stream bandwidth

2019-01-13
Declan Freeman-Gleason12:09 AM

@Darwin Clark Here’s some working code for vision tracking the 2019 targets. it uses the wpilib pi image, but also is set up for the Microsoft lifecam.

It seems pretty standard. They don’t fork a process to wait on camera reads. I haven’t read either your code or theirs in depth enough to see any interesting differences, but I thought you might get something out of it.

https://github.com/team3997/ChickenVision>

Paul Vibrans6:15 AM

I believe there is a relatively simple analog solution to the problem of reverse kinematics that were discouraging the programmers form tackling a rocket bot. If the operator's station is fitted with a scale model of the complex arm with shoulder, elbow and wrist and the model of the arm has exactly the same potentiometers at the joints as are on the real arm, and the model arm is mounted inside a physical fence that is scaled to the limits of the allowable excursion outside the frame perimeter, then the controls for the real arm only have to make the arm angles match those of the model. Each joint would have a PID controller driving the joint actuating motors. The error of the joint responses would be indicated on the model by red, yellow and green LED's with green representing error less than acceptable maximum, yellow representing some greater amount of error and red representing an arm gone rogue . A knob on the wrist of the model would be manipulated by the operator to position the model cargo intake/hatch handler on targets within the model frame perimeter that are located at the heights of the various scoring and pickup locations. The goal of the equipment operator would be to move the model arm as fast as possible while keeping the LED's in the green.

Other features such as range between the real arm and the real target could be added to the display if the robot were fitted with range finders.

Paul Vibrans6:17 AM

Pre-match tuning would be done by setting the robot arm and the model arm in the same position, against stops, and physically adjusting the potentiometers on the model to match those of the robot.

Paul Vibrans6:22 AM

The digitized values of the potentiometer outputs would need to be displayed on the operator console to assist pre-match setting and to allow the operator to see how well the arm and model track during the match.

Dana Batali9:35 AM

i guess that since we aren't doing a multi-joint arm we won't need to worry about this this year

Paul Vibrans9:39 AM

Some people want the lowbot to have a single jointed arm with wrist.

Riyadth Al-Kazily9:45 AM

My concern with any multi-joint arm is that my understanding is a part of the system COULD extend beyond the 30" boundary outside the frame perimeter, resulting in a foul. It would be up to the programmers to ensure that this never happens, and that means actual reverse kinematics, and a high dependence on accurate sensor data, repeatable mechanical response of the system, and lots of high-quality mathematics. That's a good challenge to work out during the off season.

Dana Batali9:52 AM

The concerns that @Riyadth Al-Kazily expressed were the ones I tried to describe in a recent meeting. I don't think that a single jointed arm with a wrist will require sophisticated pathing - though perhaps a rotating wrist might require additional care. The inverse kinematics problem for < 3 joints, iirc, has an analytic solution and would likely be the way to go... But we'll leave that for another season.

Riyadth Al-Kazily10:40 AM

Nice demo of vision tracking: https://twitter.com/nerdsofprey4065/status/1084254817487339520?s=21>

Paul Vibrans11:18 AM

My mostly analog approach to controlling a 3 joint arm automatically keeps the arm in bounds. The pathing would be done by a human processor that can learn. The only limitation on speed would be the power of the servos and the stability of the PID controllers. Is it necessary that all motion controls be purely digital with algorithms making the decisions based on binary inputs?

Dana Batali11:22 AM

Well, i think that's the basis of the digital revolution... :wink: (and the job security for programmers too!)

Paul Vibrans11:24 AM

The digital revolution brought us the iPhone spell check or spell corruption feature, too.

Dana Batali11:28 AM

and don't forget slack in that list!

Dana Batali12:10 PM

Interesting - it suggests that they peeled off their programmers from the design discussions so they can "prototype" ideas. Either that or they are already done with design.

Binnur Alkazily6:21 PM

In case anyone is having installation problems on linux/ubuntu, here is thread from chief delphi
https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/installation-of-the-2019-vscode-and-third-party-libraries-on-ubuntu/340789>

2019-01-14
Chris Rininger6:01 AM

Good Sandstorm auto discussion: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/knowing-where-you-are-on-the-field-after-the-6-drop-in-sandstorm/340710/11>

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:11 AM

Some MCL implementations:
- http://www.hessmer.org/robotics/monte-carlo-location-for-robots/monte-carlo-localization-implementation.html>
- https://github.com/ormanli/monte-carlo-localization>

Declan Freeman-Gleason4:59 PM

Thread on autonomous driving to the scoring target

Justice James5:15 PM

I like the simplicity of just backing up, but I also wonder if it'll make too much of an impact on cycle time.

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:17 PM

If you back directly up (onto the HAB platform) you don't really solve the problem because the bump will screw up encoder-based odometry. I also think (but cannot definitively confirm) that it's too much of a negative impact on cycle times.

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:26 PM

We have a couple of options (keep in mind that we have do accommodate the initial jump off the HAB platform when considering encoder-only/odometry solutions):
- Use a PID (we probably only need the proportional term) controller on the vision target's angle to the robot. The output of the controller feeds the difference in target velocity (not percent output, for better reliablity) between the two sides of the drivetrain. Also always have a constant feedforward velocity on both of the wheels. If this is tuned correctly, then the robot should drive to the target, but this solution will have a limited starting point that it works from.
- Use the above in the sandstorm for getting to the first target, and then when we align with that first target, zero our odometry. After this, use odometry and the path planner to get to the target (maybe with periodic zeroing). This is a nicer middle ground, but it relies on the long-term accuracy of odometry, initial effectiveness of the above solution, and periodic re-zeroing that might not be feasible.
- Augment/improve the reliability of odometry using LIDAR-based localization (ICP, MCL), and use the path planner to drive to the target's field coordinates. This requires further time investment from Dana and myself, but is potentially (long term) a very good investment. I'm not sure if we really have time for this, and I don't think I could implement MCL without a lot of help from Dana (I don't understand the algorithm well enough in detail right now).
- Use the vision, with fixed angle camera distance estimation (as described here: http://fdocs.limelightvision.io/en/latest/csestimatingdistance.html|fdocs.limelightvision.io/en/latest/csestimatingdistance.html>) to get the target's distance and angle from the robot, convert that to robot-relative cartesian coords, and use the path planner to get to those coordinates (You will need to know the robot's approximate field-relative rotation for this, because otherwise you don't really know what end angle you need. This assumes the IMU won't drift too much, which we'll need to test.) I like this option the most.
- Do the above, but with area-based distance estimation.

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:26 PM

Let me know what you think @Darwin Clark @Dana Batali

Dana Batali7:41 PM

link above should be
http://docs.limelightvision.io/en/latest/csestimatingdistance.html>

Dana Batali7:43 PM

i will spend a few more days on lidar, looking into mcl and increasing my understanding of ipc. Then I'll be more opinionated :slightlysmilingface:

Dana Batali7:43 PM

I hope to do this wed&thurs while y'all slave away at finals (good luck!) :slightlysmilingface:

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:53 PM

Sounds good… Thanks Dana!

Binnur Alkazily9:14 PM

also curious about using distance sensors to help w/ adjusting for the initial jump from the HAB using the back wall as the target. this will take us down the path of how well we can fuse the sensor readings

Darwin Clark9:33 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason On a first pass, it seems you haven't mentioned line following? What are your thoughts on alignment using sensors (Either in an array or a set) mounted on the underbelly of the robot to trace the line? @Binnur Alkazily FWIW, It's likely we will be using something similar to ultrasound (which we have an abundance of thanks to @Randy Groves ) for hatch intake/delivery system, as they want to have a sensor detecting when the hatch is misaligned on the intake.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:37 PM

Line following, as I understand it, isn’t optimal because once the driver is aligned well enough for us to follow the line, the human has done everything that we can speed up through automation (i.e. they’ve done the difficult horizontal alignment). Also, the line doesn’t tell us how far away (in x and y) we are from our target.

Binnur Alkazily9:39 PM

Depends on the range and sensitivity of the device — @Riyadth Al-Kazily mentioned they maybe short distances, and looking at the field the back wall is min of 95” once robot leaves the platform. In terms of the line following, I am not seeing many lines on the field, but otherwise another sensor input to consider.

Binnur Alkazily9:58 PM

Potentially relevant ideas from this thread — I like the creativity of using a ping pong ball w/ driver station camera to detect robot’s location
https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/most-accurate-form-of-localization/166379/38>

Binnur Alkazily10:04 PM

Another reading from Chief Delphi — potentially good background on the FRC localization problem as someone’s research report
https://web.wpi.edu/Pubs/E-project/Available/E-project-042418-200712/unrestricted/final_report.pdf>

2019-01-16
Dana Batali9:42 AM

For those interested in learning more about odometry and how we track our robot position through a match, I prepared an overview/introduction doc here:

https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/master/OdometryNotes.md>

Feedback on how to make it better always welcome!

Paul Vibrans11:39 AM

You left out the non-powered wheel encoder, which is the sensor preferred by Roboctopi.

Dana Batali11:51 AM

wasn't aware of it. Do you have a link or a brand-name?

Riyadth Al-Kazily1:11 PM

I think it is something we would make ourselves. Simply a wheel mounted to an encoder, with no motor on it. I think an omni wheel would be best, so it doesn't skip or vibrate when turning.

Dana Batali1:14 PM

i'm confused: with only a single measurement we'd only be measuring distance traveled and have no indication of heading. Right? We'd still need two of these?

Declan Freeman-Gleason1:15 PM

Yeah... Wouldn't it be two omni wheels?

Dana Batali1:15 PM

i suppose it could be combined with the gyro reading (that might work)

Riyadth Al-Kazily1:16 PM

You could use two if differential measurement is the goal. I guess you could also put one in the center of the robot, and account for turning/angle in some other way? (I can envision a caster being dragged behind the robot with a potentiometer to indicate angle, and encoder for distance, and then we sample both distance and angle repeatedly to build up our "path")

Paul Vibrans2:34 PM

Roboctopi make their own widely separated, spring loaded wheels on the chassis to provide forward motion input that can be used for calculating yaw, too. They are not a difficult mechanical problem and I wonder why we have not used them to get away from the powered wheel problems. We could do both.

In the vscode `>wpilib: check wpilib update` for online finds the updated library. But, I recall being advised to install using ‘offline’. Any thoughts on that for upgrades?

2019-01-23
Binnur Alkazily11:01 AM

Team, I won’t be at today’s meeting. Subsystem leads, I’d like you to outline how you will test+verify hardware/electronics in your subsystems using Dashboard (or other methods) — I’ll be checking on this during Friday’s meeting. Use cases you need to think about are:
- How do you know the motors are wired correctly and rotating in the directions you think they should
- How do you know sensors are functioning accurately
- How can you quickly tune any parameters, like motor speeds, without having to run all your subsystem code
- Is there a subsystem checklist for your area that should be reported — think from the aspect of a launch checklist that ensures your subsystem is fully operational and ready
- Are there any critical elements of your subsystem that should be reported to the driver during competition
As a note, items above is a required way to ensure your dependencies are working correctly before you start debugging the functionality of your subsystem.
^^^ @Ronan Bennett @Austin Smith @Justice James @Ryan Olney

Binnur Alkazily6:00 PM

@Camden Greenhalgh 2018 refactored arduino code for the LED

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:20 PM

@Dana Batali Dynamic path generation is working (mostly; there are a couple of things to work out). The robot drives back to its origin in this example.

Paths appear to be generated in 20±10ms. We are using the nonlinear feedback controller, with untuned (!) gains. This had noticeably better performance than the adaptive pure pursuit controller.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1EMtnczymD5h2xoZX65qSktqWHbzjt1nQ/view?usp=drivesdk>

2019-01-26
Dana Batali9:57 AM

here's what I recall doing:
1. i didn't let the uv4l run as a service.
2. i started uv4l manually (before connecting via python). I ran that on the default port (8080).
3. i verified that I could see the uv4l feed from the dashboard (made appropriate changes to layout.json).
4. i started picamStreamer.py (haven't made the same mods to picamStreamerAlgo.py) - and it runs on port 5080 (and streams mjpeg). Made the changes to layout.json).

Dana Batali10:10 AM

a question of priority:

- depending on whether the drivers can accept the constraints of vision or vice-versa, it's possible that this activity will be "moot".
- for example, if measuring distances requires an approximately horizontal-pointing camera (i think it does), and the driver wants an over-the-shoulder view, we might conflicting requirements.
- this suggests that picking vision priorities is the first order of business?

Binnur Alkazily10:31 AM

Good discussion regarding to hatch panel placement w/ vision and OpenCV solvePnP() for pose estimation. Note: it also has a reference to a nice background on vision processing
@Darwin Clark @Martin Vroom ^^^
https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/hatch-panel-alignment/343233/2>

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:49 AM

Just leaving this phenomenal looking book here: https://file.tavsys.net/control/state-space-guide.pdf>

It goes through a lot of control theory (and associated concepts), but is intended for students in FRC.

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:40 PM

@Dana Batali Path following seems to work, but I had forgotten about this comment until now: https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/41129c747670a3764ff6af2dc63d2c92202320d0/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/lib/physics/DifferentialDrive.java#L319>

This means that we're probably applying erroneous constraints to the acceleration as a result of our max voltage constraint, but if it things seem to work then we may be OK. It's that, or we can verify their math (Which could be a good exercise, but maybe isn't appropriate for our current stage in the build season? We would also need to find a reference for this implementation.)

Darwin Clark3:05 PM

Great point. At the meeting on Friday (1/25), @Martin Vroom and I hashed out what we want to accomplish with vision this year, and where vision will fit into our cycles. Bear with me as I try to translate a verbal presentation into text :slightlysmilingface: . We discussed what elements of navigation are going to be challenges for the driver. We came up a few: loading station alignment, alignment with cargo ship receptacles, and HAB climbing alignment to name just a few. After exchanges with @Chris Mentzer, we decided a reasonable implementation for vision is perpendicular alignment with the cargo ship receptacles (NOT placement accuracy, which will be addressed separately). We imagine a cycle where the driver acquires a game piece, then in the greater cargo ship area (I can't think of a good word to describe this... Think of the space between the allied rocket, and the cargo ship) press a button and autonomous vision control takes over. How we would go about this in software is mostly going to be decided robot-side (Chiefly continuous input though a PID vs. one-shot path generation). Once we are perpendicularly aligned, it will be the responsibility of the driver and driver aid cams (non-vision) to accurately align to the target. We discussed this full idea with @Ronan Bennett @Binnur Alkazily @Chris Mentzer and @Declan Freeman-Gleason. My personal objective from the last meeting was to have a plan of action, and an overall objective, which I feel we have accomplished at a high level of abstraction. Speaking from a purely strategical/high-level standpoint: what do you think of this idea, and how can we improve it?

Darwin Clark3:07 PM

Darwin Clark3:07 PM

Or are you saying that's all that the task requires?

In terms of what we need, here’s a possible approach:
1. Enumerate all possible goals
2. Rank/prioritize each goal
3. List unknowns for each goal
4. Put together a schedule; because we have so many unknowns, just schedule into the next few meetings. E.g. only schedule answering questions needed to move forward on goal number one. Later on when the unknowns are gone we can schedule more.

Binnur Alkazily2:19 PM

I am good at overly simplifying things :slightlysmilingface: but, I recall working on this list w/ @Darwin Clark during the kickoff weekend. I really recommend to keep things simple — there are limited number of tasks where vision can help w/ cycles:
1. Pick up panel
2. Pick up ball
3. Deliver panel
4. Deliver ball
5. Drive/align for L3 climb

For each of those, decide cost/benefit on vision vs. raw camera data for the driver. This approach should help you narrow and focus vision work. Or, just pick the one you want to do and just do it!

Dana Batali2:56 PM

There are only 4 or 5 questions at the top that need to be clearly answered and designed and I suspect we can get that done in two hours. We'll then need sign-off from the robot-control team (ie declan).

I see that darwyn filled out much of the deliverables schedule section, but the first section is still in questions-only form. In my mind the deliverables follow from the decision of what we're going for.

Finally, i'm all for just doing it but the team seems to be striving for more formality+process this year.

Declan Freeman-Gleason4:33 PM

Vision Requirements
Deliverable: Get the target x, y, and perpendicular relative to the robot
- x, y, and perpindicular accurate enough so that we can get within 2-4 inches of the target
- Give us space separated "x y perpindiculartheta timetooktocompute_ms" in robot relative coordinate system
~ Delivered to "SmartDashboard/Vision/{ALGO NAME}/Target
 Optional deliverable: Just give yaw

Dana Batali2:14 PM

@Darwin Clark: i suspect that the success/failure solvePnP returns is more about whether it was able to perform the math successfully and not whether it was passed the correct arguments. This isn't uncommon: to eliminated lots of needless checking of input parameters, it's typical to expect that the caller provides inputs that follow the specification. In other words, it doesn't make sense to call a function without the correct inputs and it's the caller's responsibility to check for this and avoid the call.

I spose the bigger issue is why your routine isn't successful in delivering 6 points?

Declan Freeman-Gleason3:03 PM

Starting a thread on an interesting path planning bug:

When we set up a path with two waypoints (in field coordinates), from (0, 0, 0°) to (78, 78, 90°) and run the path, the robot goes to (according to odometry) (something around 78, some around -78, and something around -90°).

This is obviously wrong.

Declan Freeman-Gleason3:07 PM

I have a couple of theories:
1. Things are getting reversed somewhere incorrectly... This piece of code may be the culprit (but it also means we have other problems in our path): https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/compare/8e7f98b348cd...ec00c531e224#diff-978f961c79799159cb5a09588ad899a5R88> I just put a print statement there so we can check and see the next time we run this.
2. The robot turns in a way the kinematics/dynamics don't expect (e.g. we want to turn right, but our command makes us turn left)? I'm not sure if this makes sense, because I would expect the path follower to freak out if this is the case.

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:09 PM

The `true` here gets the mirrored version of our trajectory, which is a version where every state of the trajectory has a negated Y and a "inversed" (sin is negated) rotation. https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/ec00c531e224431c53fbb846e8ad35c4fe735068/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/frc2019/auto/modes/PathTestMode.java#L27>

I need to be more careful, apparently!

Dana Batali5:10 PM

aha - you got what you asked for!

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:10 PM

Sure did!

Mark Tarlton6:25 PM

The Cargo Chute subsystem (currently) is using one motor for moving cargo and a pneumatic cylinder to raise and lower it between two set positions.

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:46 PM

By the way, we’re basically doing some parts of characterization wrong… The approach in this code considers more stuff (e.g. battery voltage), and does something better than a linear regression to get kA. Things work ok now, so we might not want to worry immediately.

See:
https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/paper-frc-drivetrain-characterization/160915>
 https://github.com/robotpy/robot-characterization>

2019-01-30
Riyadth Al-Kazily8:20 AM

Vision peeps (@Darwin Clark ) here is a whitepaper for your reading pleasure. I have been following the Ligerbots for a while now, and I think they know some stuff. https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/a-step-by-step-run-through-of-frc-vision-processing/341012>

Dana Batali9:18 AM

i did a quick scan and it looks quite easy to read with lots of interesting information. They did make a slightly unusual choice for co-processor and as a side-effect had to give up the picam. THere are lots of interesting tidbits here - like the different latencies at different competitions, questions about robot mounts + wiring, etc. They are using the PnP approach plus python plus opencv.

Dana Batali9:23 AM

nice! - more fodder for the PnP approach. Curious if they have any comments on speed, latency, efficacy, etc.

Now that we're using the FRCVision pi-image, it hadn't occurred to me that java was an option.

Here are some pros and cons wrt java vs python:

Pro
• easier transition between robot code and vision code
• easier to write the threaded computation of capture + process
• better static analysis stability guarantees

Con
• no performance advantage over python since they share underlying opencv implementations.
• requires compilation step, so potentially less "interactive"
• less concise than python
• new learning to get a picamStreamer http mjpeg streamer to work.
• may/may-not have adequate picamera controls

Dana Batali11:03 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: first doc is nice and clear. Some notes:

• i agree that our values for ks,kv,ka may be good enough, but we should be calculating them on a carpet with approximately the correct weight distribution.
• sadly there is no discussion of angular acceleration nor inertial moments
• their static friction coefficient: 1.26V
• wear on the wheels over the season requires updating the wheel radius.

Great discussion of acceleration variability:

However, the dynamic case is not analogous: friction between the gears will clearly vary with acceleration, as the normal force between gear teeth is proportional to the output torque of the motors, and thus to robot acceleration. Thus, the amount by which our empirical value of ka is inﬂated from the theoretical is representative of the torsional loss from the motors to the wheels as a result of frictional eﬀects that vary with load. From these data, it appears that the drive of our test robot loses over half of its motor torque to such losses.


On batteries and voltage compensation: (we currently enable voltage compensation in drive and don't employ voltage ramp-rate)


A number of caveats apply to our suggested methodology, however. Firstly, it is absolutely crucial that some step be taken to account for “voltage sag” due to the internal resistance of the battery and resistance of the robot’s wiring. The Talon SRX motor controller oﬀers a “closed-loop voltage compensation” option that does a ﬁne job of accomplishing this; battery voltage monitoring via the PDP can also be used to apply the necessary correction.

Dana Batali11:31 AM

some data from another team:

https://gist.github.com/JayShower/eeda672aa3033b457da113aa625c85e0>

their Ks was 1.4V


Additionally, I looked through your data a bit and it seems you didn’t quite trim the quasi-static data enough; there are still a number of points at which the robot wasn’t moving (visible as a “flat” portion at the start of the velocity plot). I’ve re-calculated your values with a more-appropriate trimming (I removed all velocities under 2 inches per second), and taken the liberty of putting them in a spreadsheet of a form similar to my own - I’ll fill in the theoretical values when you report the drive specs:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1CIVKGqqm4LwO7mLslABxu3YxWHJK3PwnfQV-vEIJOoU/edit?usp=sharing>

Dana Batali11:39 AM

wasn't aware wolfram alpha has auto-unit management:

https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=6++343+ozfin++6.1++2+%2F+(4+inches+*+110+lbm)>

Dana Batali11:53 AM

conclusions from related thread https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/the-great-drive-base-performance-characterization-data-sharing-thread/162243/37>


So, while there’s limited data in the thread so far, from the data I’ve seen in this thread (and some additional data from some of our other robots that I’ll get around in posting eventually), it seems the standard for a “healthy” robot drive is a velocity efficiency in the neighborhood of 90-100%, an acceleration efficiency around 70%, and a voltage intercept in the neighborhood of 1-1.5 volts (tending to be lower if gearing is higher).

In practice, this means Kv will generally have a value of ~1-1.1 times that of theoretical, and Ka will generally have a value of ~1.4 times that of theoretical. So, if you need to “bootstrap” values when you don’t have time to run the actual tests, this is probably a safe bet.

If you see acceleration efficiencies much below 70%, you should probably check your drive for sources of inefficiency.


And the important constraints of maxV vs maxA:


From the voltage balance equation, we see that Vapp = Kv velocity + Ka acceleration Vintercept. If we limit ourselves to 9V (to allow room for voltage sag and extra headroom for the controller), we thus must pick our maximum velocity and acceleration values such that Kvvmax + Kaamax + Vintercept = 9 volts. As I mentioned earlier, this equation clearly shows that we have a “tradeoff” between maximum velocity and maximum acceleration - the higher we allow one to be, the lower we must make the other to ensure that our setpoints are achievable.

For instance, if we pick a maximum velocity of 6 ft/s, then our maximum acceleration must be (9 - .76 6 - .78)/.27 = 13.5 feet per second squared.*

Dana Batali12:02 PM

another chief delphi thread (254):
https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/team-254-presents-lockdown-technical-binder-2018/166515/69>


The optimization function is simple iterated gradient descent 1. At iteration N+1, we compute the partial derivatives on rate of change of curvature w.r.t. arc length for the curve at iteration N, then take a step in the direction that minimizes the magnitude of the derivative. Keep iterating until you hit a termination condition (max number of iterations, or the improvement between the last two iterations is too small).

For following, we did not use pure pursuit except at our first event. After AZ North we finished our nonlinear feedback controller 3 and used that going forward. This controller generates velocity setpoints based on the current pose of the robot and feedforward velocity and acceleration terms from our trajectory.

Our feedforward generation techniques used a dynamic model 2 of a skid-steer drivetrain to generate voltage setpoints that account for torques due to chassis linear acceleration, chassis angular acceleration, and a variety of friction effects.

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:09 PM

By the way, section 4.5.2 of the State Space book outlines calculating moment of inertia for a differential drive.

https://file.tavsys.net/control/state-space-guide.pdf#page41>

Dana Batali12:13 PM

agreed - i referred to those elsewhere as chapter 4ish
- fwiw: not sure why #page41 is in the link... The section number is accurate.

Dana Batali12:19 PM

two comments from our 254 code (in DifferentialDrive.java)


// Equivalent moment of inertia when accelerating purely angularly, in kgm^2.
// This is "equivalent" in that it also absorbs the effects of drivetrain inertia.
// Measure by doing drivetrain acceleration characterization while turning in place.
protected final double moi;

// Drag torque (proportional to angular velocity) that resists turning, in Nm/rad/s
// Empirical testing of our drivebase showed that there was an unexplained loss in torque ~proportional to angular
// velocity, likely due to scrub of wheels.
// NOTE: this may not be a purely linear term, and we have done limited testing, but this factor helps our model to
// better match reality. For future seasons, we should investigate what's going on here...
protected final double angulardrag_;

Dana Batali12:53 PM

comment on passive odometry (a-la paul's suggestion):


Those were passive follower omniwheels that got sprung into the ground to provide odometry information. In practice there were a number of deflection and slipping issues which made them less accurate than just using standard wheel odometry (after switching to nitrile tread in the center + corner omnis).

Dana Batali1:20 PM

more from the chief delphi thread:


angular drag?

Gathering data, then fitting the parameters to what we saw. Our exact procedure for this was something like:

Determine the parameters for straight line motion (the Kv, Ka, and friction params that are now well known from the drivetrain characterization paper).

Assume that we know the load in the linear case (given that it’s mostly mass, assumes drivetrain inertia is negligible). This lets us derive a torque constant Kt from the Ka parameter above.

Do a drivetrain characterization run (constant velocity run for Kv, then slow ramp of motor voltage for friction and Ka) in a turn-in-place test to measure an angular Ka parameter.

Assume the same amount of torque is available in the turn-in-place case as in the linear case. Now use algebra to figure out what the moment of inertia must be to account for the angular Ka we measured.

Angular drag was added later, because we were seeing “velocity losses” that were unexplainable otherwise. We were seeing a drag force ~proportional to speed. This is probably due to scrubbing. We tuned the parameter until our observed plots ~matched our model.

Dana Batali1:23 PM


In regards to this, could you clarify what equation you used to turn these two Ka values into moment-of-inertia? It’s not immediately apparent from the drivetrain characterization paper or the code used to do the characterization how this conversion is made.




Sure. The Ka “acceleration constant” you get from the drivetrain characterization paper is a convenient representation, and mathematically sound, but it doesn’t really decompose into real-world engineering units. That paper basically comes up with the formula:


Voltage applied to motor = Friction voltage + Kv velocity + Ka acceleration

Make one subtle change and you’ll obtain the formulas we used. Instead of Ka acceleration, we used a Kt torque term.

The relationship between the two is straightforward in the linear case:


Torque / wheel radius = linear acceleration robot mass

(technically you can add other loads, like the inertia of the drive transmission itself, into the robot “mass”. Also, be sure to account for gear ratios somewhere.)

We simply used our measured robot mass and wheel radius to convert from the observed Ka to a Kt value.

Now, run the same experiment again but turn-in-place, and you’ll observe a different Ka value than you did in the linear case. Why? Because the load is different (now the moment of inertia of the robot turning about its center vs. the mass):


Torque / wheel radius effective wheelbase radius = angular acceleration * robot moi

2019-01-31
Dana Batali9:31 AM

vision thread week 4

Dana Batali9:32 AM

@Darwin Clark: consider the following chunks of numpy


a = np.array(0)
b = np.array([])

(a is array(0), b is array([], dtype=float64))


np.append(b, [1,2,3])
c = np.append(b, [1,2,3])
c = np.append(c, [4,5,6])

b isn't changed: `array([])`
c is now `array([1,2,3,4,5,6])` (ie: its flattened)


d = np.array([[1,2], [3,4], [5,6]])


d is now:

array([[1, 2],
[3, 4],
[5, 6]])


so the easiest thing to do will be to construct a python list of lists, then create a numpy array from that.
In other words, a numpy array has very different semantics from a python list:


>>> i = []
>>> i.append((1,2))
>>> i
[(1, 2)]
>>> i.append((3,4))
>>> i
[(1, 2), (3, 4)]
>>> j = np.array(i)
>>> j
array([[1, 2],
[3, 4]])


and a few more tidbits:


>>> contour = np.array([[0,0], [0,1], [1,0], [1,1]])
>>> contour
array([[0, 0],
[0, 1],
[1, 0],
[1, 1]])
>>> bbox = cv2.minAreaRect(contour)
>>> bbox
((0.5, 0.5), (1.0, 1.0), -90.0)

(a bbox is given by its center, its size and its rotation angle)


>>> boxPts = cv2.boxPoints(bbox)
>>> boxPts
array([[ 1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+00],
[ -3.06161713e-17, 1.00000000e+00],
[ 0.00000000e+00, 0.00000000e+00],
[ 1.00000000e+00, 0.00000000e+00]], dtype=float32)

Darwin Clark10:31 AM

@Dana Batali In your first example, would c be a 2d array? (Array of arrays) You've instantied b as an numpy.array() containing 1 empty vanilla python array, and are then appending another vanilla array to it, do I have that right?

Dana Batali10:36 AM

np.append generally seems to flatten things, which is why the best approach is to build standard python lists, then convert to np.array at the end

Randy Groves2:24 PM

Probably too late in the game, but it's intruiging: https://hackaday.com/2019/01/31/ai-on-raspberry-pi-with-the-intel-neural-compute-stick/>

2019-02-01
Dana Batali10:45 AM

@Darwin Clark: a couple more thoughts on the current state of vision affairs:

I'm concerned that the current camera settings (in picam.py) aren't well suited for the competition. When looking at the new "mask" algo, we get lots of instability. I suspect this may have something to do with the fireworks exposure setting. I was able to get a much more stable result with very high contrast, manual exposure settings. I discovered that frcvision is a reasonable way to play with these setttings. Here's the recipe:

1. make sure no picamStreamer is running
2. in the frcvision dashboard (Vision Settings), add a camera and save. Note that after we have our settings, we'll remove it and save.
3. make sure that their multi-camera-service is running (frcvision/Application)
4. open the camera stream. THere i see a whole pile of sliders, etc. The mjpg stream i see there seems like a great tool to select all the camera/exposure (but not the stream) settings.
5. if, as you suggest, color isn't important to our algorithm, i'd suggest we eliminate the colorspace conversion and threshold the input image directly

i found these settings to work in my home setup:
> contrast: 100
> saturation: 0
> brightness: 20
> auto_exposure: manual, etc

thoughts?

2019-02-02
Dana Batali8:32 AM

@Randy Groves asked me to dig up some brain cells on last year's IR sensor. Well, here they are:

1. the data-sheet formula didn't match our actual experiment. So I recall Randy collecting several points, then producing a cubic polynomial via an online resource.
2. this formula is embedded in last year's sensor code here:https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2018-POWERUP/blob/master/src/com/spartronics4915/lib/util/drivers/SpartIRSensor.java#L70>
3. the point of this method is to produce a distance measured in inches given the voltage measured by the roborio.
4. each sensor model would have a different response curve and I imagine we could add support for the different models to SpartIRSensor by repeating the measurement steps for each model. One hopes/expects that the variance between components of the same model is small enough that we won't need to characterize every component. Clients of this class could, for example, construct an instance with a parameter signalling the model. If we adopt the convention that a cubic polynomial will be used to represent the curve, then the only thing that distinguishes one model from another is the 4 numbers required. These could be instance variables of the class and they can be initialized base on the model number.

@Binnur Alkazily mentioned that many uses for this sensor will produce a binary choice (captured/not-captured, ...) based on a threshold. I would recommend that this threshold be described as a range of inches rather than volts since its a very intuitive (and linear!) unit.

@Austin Smith: mycurvefit seems like a perfectly acceptable site to do the "regression analysis". I would recommend that you collect points for your sensors and fit a cubic polynomial to it. Voltages for 10ish distances should be sufficient. I imagine that an exponential curve isn't as good a choice for two reasons: 1. it doesn't capture the curve that Randy actually measured last year. 2. it's more expensive to evaluate that a cubic polynomial.

Finally (whew): what is a cubic polynomial? Think of it as a fancy line where instead of the usual line formula (`y = A + Bx`), we have this:


inches = A + Bv + Cvv + Dvvv; // v is volts

And the values A, B, C, D are provided by MyCurveFit.

Lane Johnson8:40 AM

@Lane Johnson has joined the channel

Randy Groves9:54 AM

Thanks @Dana Batali for the recall effort - that rings bells. I should have commented this!

Austin Smith10:44 AM

Yes, thank you very much!

Binnur Alkazily10:50 AM

@Dana Batali thanks for the details on the past, but I feel I am missing something... The equation that is used in the github code that you linked is identical to the data sheet I linked above for A41 which is the sensor we used last year. If there is a data discrapency, then I am not seeing it. However, if we say that the data sheet equation is good as we also used it in our code last year, than I think evaluating the new A41 sensor readings and regression analysis against that data sheet would be a good verification & validation step.

Randy Groves11:10 AM

The calulation in the code is the cubic polynomial and not the formula in the datasheet. Dana is right - I took some data points from observation, and created the code from that.

Binnur Alkazily11:13 AM

Cool! I am corrected - thanks for the clarification!

Noah Solomon12:05 PM

Austin Smith12:06 PM

Austin Smith12:08 PM

v for voltage.

Noah Solomon12:08 PM

Noah Solomon12:09 PM

Noah Solomon12:10 PM

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:10 PM

@Noah Solomon You will actually need to instantiate a new `IRSensor` object. The constructor takes an `int` (for the port number). Then you can call `isTargetInDistanceRange`.

See the implementation here: https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/master/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/lib/drivers/IRSensor.java>

Noah Solomon12:12 PM

What should I import?

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:12 PM

`com.spartronics4915.lib.drivers.IRSensor`

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:12 PM

See https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/05ce9c0a22c681e956942f4b5b59be8a34b62a9a/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/frc2019/subsystems/CargoIntake.java#L54> and https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/05ce9c0a22c681e956942f4b5b59be8a34b62a9a/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/frc2019/subsystems/CargoIntake.java#L67> for example usage.

Austin Smith2:14 PM

For people using IR Sensors, you're going to have to change the instantiation to be A21IRSensor (10-80 cm) or A41IRSensor (4-30 cm) as IRSensor has been made into an abstract class.
