Binnur Alkazily4:31 PM

@Austin Smith @Ryan Olney @Justice James ^^^

Dana Batali6:15 PM

@Darwin Clark: I think i misunderstood a point that @Riyadth Al-Kazily was making about the potential of a usb camera. I now understand that the interest is to reduce the number of raspis on the robot from 4 to 2 and that we could potentially get there by employing a picam for driver /h264 and usbcam for vision. In the application that we're currently heading toward: PNP at one point in time to feed the path-planner, we can probably afford the slower frame-rate inherent in the usbcams. If we need to feed the "inner loop" of the robot control, then we'd really need the faster framerates. I expect that wiring in a usb camera is a straightforward task and will likely test it out before the next meeting. I expect that the changes required will be outside of algo.py (which is why we organized the code that way). Extra costs to this approach: we'd need to repeat the investment you made in tuning the exposure / contrast settings which differ from those of the raspi. Other "risks" that I can think of: we'll need to consider the additional power consumption of the usbcam. (of course the draw of the second camera will definitely be less than an entire raspi).

So the summary is: I'll do a little work to validate the use of a usbcam. If it passes the validation, we can evaluate the pros and cons from a system-wide perspective and go from there.

Dana Batali6:20 PM

@Binnur Alkazily: here's the "nose" video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NIgKWr4OxoE>

and the tutorial:

https://www.learnopencv.com/head-pose-estimation-using-opencv-and-dlib/>

Dana Batali6:37 PM

@Martin Vroom: here's a little snippet we can use to overlay a canvas atop a video element:


var zindex = 15;
var canvas = document.createElement("canvas");
canvas.className = 'canvases'; // maybe set id too
canvas.style.border = '2px solid red';
canvas.style.zIndex = zindex;
zindex++;
var parentDiv = document.getElementById("video");
parentDiv.appendChild(canvas);


this presumes a .css like this:

.canvases {
width: 100%;
height:100%;
border:1px solid;
position:absolute;
pointer-events: none;
}

Martin Vroom6:46 PM

Thanks, I'll work on that this evening.

2019-02-03
Randy Groves8:30 AM

Randy Groves8:35 AM

Found a source for the GP2Y0A02YK0F and the GP2Y0A41SK0F in the robotpy code. Look in https://github.com/robotpy/robotpy-wpilib-utilities> in the robotpyext/commondrivers/distance_sensors.py file. Equation for the A02 is:

62.28x ^ -1.092 where x is the voltage. Distance in cm

Equation for the A41 is:

12.84x ^ -0.9824 where x is the voltage. Distance in cm

Dana Batali9:24 AM

@Darwin Clark: do you remember seeing a microsoft usbcam in my vision box? I was looking for it at home and haven't yet found it

Justice James10:25 AM

@Austin Smith

Darwin Clark11:47 AM

@Dana Batali I do remember seeing one...

Mike Rosen2:53 PM

Can someone confirm that last year we connected the Arduino / LED strip to the RoboRio using the USB/Serial converter as opposed to directly coming off the RoboRio's RS-232 pins. @Ronan Bennett @Ryan Olney

The Bling team is having challenges talking to the Arduino card (which runs the LED strip) from the RoboRio. We've confirmed that the Arduino program correctly drives the LED strip when we talk to it via the USB/Serial connection hooked up to the dev laptop. However, when we connected the same USB cable to the RoboRio, it fails to respond. We're using last year's code as a template, in particular the Robot sets up the serial port like this:


mBling = new SerialPort(9600, SerialPort.Port.kUSB);



One would think that this would mean that the USB/Serial cable would work. But it's not. Any thoughts on this?

Declan Freeman-Gleason3:35 PM

@Mike Rosen We may have come right off the pins last year... @Riyadth Al-Kazily might remember.

My guesses for why it's not working:
- `SerialPort.Port.kUSB` might be the USB type B port. You should try `kUSB1` and `kUSB2`.
- We may need to disable the RIO's console out feature. This can be done on the Silverlight web dashboard or RoboRIO Imaging Utility. See: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/help-with-roborio-serial-ports/140172/2>

Riyadth Al-Kazily6:15 PM

The Arduino was always connected to the RoboRIO via USB (creating an emulated or "virtual" asynchronous serial port on the RoboRIO). It was never connected directly to the RS-232 pins, and in fact that is not possible to do without an intermediate protocol converter (since RS-232 voltages are not compatible with the Arduino, and can damage the chip).
Note that last year we never got the bling code communicating well with the Arduino, because the Arduino code we had last year was not "interruptable" with new commands from the RoboRIO. Development of the software was incomplete, and then due to a wiring error on the robot, the LED bling strip was burned out. So that year's robot code is not a good place to go for reference.
During the spring, we rebuilt Atlas, and also worked to get the RoboRIO and Arduino talking together. I believe the code for that combination is in a much better state to start from.
See https://github.com/Spartronics4915/Atlas> and https://github.com/riyadth/Bling/tree/riyadth/refactor> (note this is my "refactor" branch of the bling code).
kUSB should be the correct serial port. It doesn't refer to the A or B USB ports, but rather to the serial device instance on the RoboRIO, based on the number of USB serial devices detected by the operating system. We may need to log in to the RoboRIO with a shell to diagnose whether or not the Arduino is being properly detected by the RoboRIO. I can help with that at the next meeting.

Riyadth Al-Kazily6:16 PM

I believe this code for Atlas was working correctly:
https://github.com/Spartronics4915/Atlas/blob/master/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/atlas/subsystems/LED.java>

Mike Rosen7:51 PM

thanks. This is indeed the reference we were using. I'll double check the Arduino side.

Riyadth Al-Kazily7:52 PM

A good thing to check would be to see if the RoboRIO code detects an error when trying to open the kUSB serial port when no Arduino is connected. It should fail, because there is no virtual serial port in the system if the Arduino is not plugged in. If the Java code does not fail without an Arduino, then we need to find out why.

Mike Rosen8:03 PM

@Camden Greenhalgh and I did try that. The Robot code crashed on load as I recall. I suspect Camden probably used the pre-exisiting Arduino project as a starting point. I'll review it with him to see if the problem is on that end ... it worked with the console app thing that's part of their IDE.

Camden Greenhalgh8:03 PM

Thanks

Riyadth Al-Kazily8:06 PM

The pre-existing bling project under Spartronics will not change from one bling pattern to another when the signal is given from the serial port. It delays until the bling sequence is done. My refactor code shows how to interrupt the bling. Camden has access to this code and we talked about it briefly. I think it would be good if we three get together at the next meeting and debug some of these connection issues.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:07 PM

Dana Batali5:31 PM

drive tuning thread week 5

Dana Batali5:33 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason (and anyone else interested)... I just updated https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/blob/master/notes/DrivetrainCharacterization.md>

Hopefully it'll help with drive characterization and ongoing path-planning. In particular i discovered a discrepancy between the 254 and statespace-guide on how to get the moment of inertia.

Feedback / fixes encouraged.

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:35 PM

Looks good... I'll refer Jeffery to this. I really appreciate all the work you're doing to document this.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:51 PM

So I looked at the two equations for a while, and it looks like the left side of 254's equation (`torque / wheel radius effective wheelbase radius = angular acceleration robot moi`) is a substition into 4.25 of the state space book.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:51 PM

The units also work out.

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:52 PM

I asked Tyler, the person who wrote the state space book, on the FRC Discord and this was his response:
"the units work out, but idk where they got the effective wheelbase radius thing"
"I think it's just a tradeoff between a more accurate r_b resulting in a different J. one absorbs errors in the other in the linear regression."

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:30 PM

@Dana Batali @Darwin Clark Today I learned that we should not change the update rate of the network tables client in the vision code. According to a WPILib maintainer this desyncs the update rate and results in a "seesaw latency graph". Instead we should call `NetworkTables.flush()` after each vision update.

2019-02-05
Dana Batali8:33 AM

Nice sleuthing!

Dana Batali11:52 AM

here's another item to consider:

"Effective" kinematic wheelbase radius. Might be larger than theoretical to compensate for skid steer. Measure by turning the robot in place several times and figuring out what the equivalent wheelbase radius is.

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:06 PM

What does “figuring out what equivalent wheelbase radius is” entail?

Dana Batali12:49 PM

Our kinematics model says this:

s.angular = kWheelRadius (wmotion.right - wmotion.left) / kWheelbaseDiameter;


If we apply the correct wheel motions (here, perhaps in PositionControlMode) to account for, say 5 chassis rotations, the question is does the final angle reflect that. If the angle is off in a repeatable fashion, then we'd tweak the kWheelbaseDiameter so that the final angle is 5360.

(and yes, the 254 comments could be clearer ;-))

Dana Batali1:18 PM

ah - this is where "scrub factor" hits the road:
DriveMotionPlanner constructs a differential drive via:

Units.inchestometers(Constants.kDriveWheelTrackWidthInches / 2.0 * Constants.kTrackScrubFactor),


So the ScrubFactor is the tuning parameter that is a multiplier for the wheelbase. And the current value (.624) seems pretty extreme to my inexperienced eye.

Dana Batali1:35 PM

noted that jaci's pathfinder requires this calibration:


Pathfinder requires some knowledge about your robot. The most important measurement is the maximum velocity, which can be either calculated or measured emperically.

Measuring the velocity is the best option, and can be done in multiple ways:

Drive at full speed in a straight line. After allowing the robot to reach max speed, measure the distance it covers within a certain amount of time.
Drive at full speed in a circle. Time how long it takes to do 10 rotations, and use the formula for circumference C = 2pir with r = track radius to calculate the distance travelled in total, dividing by 10 * time to get max velocity.

2019-02-06
Declan Freeman-Gleason3:54 PM

Ronan Bennett7:32 PM

2019-02-08
Mark Tarlton5:33 PM

Head's up for the programming team. It looks to me like we won't be able to have the chute in the high position (used to eject into cargo ship) while the Intake arms are fully upright. There's an interference issue between the two systems that I don't think we can solve.

I believe this may be significant if we adopt the policy where the intake arms are kept upright except when actively intaking cargo. This policy will help prevent damage to the intake system while navigating the floor. This restriction suggests that as soon as Cargo is ejected to the Cargo Ship, we should lower the Chute in preparation for the next intake cycle.

As I see it, the rules will be something like:
(1) for raising the arms: If chute is up, then first lower the chute, then raise the intake arms.
(2) for raising the chute: If Intake is up, then first lower the arms (to the intake position), then raise the chute.

<#CFJ4HG490|chuteteam> <#CFHV28QNQ|cargointake>

Justice James6:08 PM

Do you have a CAD file or drawing showing the interference? I'm having trouble visualizing it.

Mark Tarlton6:31 PM

https://a360.co/2DmA1fS> When the chute is down, the top bar is below and behind the arm. When the chute is up, the bar is above and forward of the arm. that's the interference problem.

Justice James6:35 PM

Thanks!

Mark Tarlton6:40 PM

there's a more subtle issue here as well. If the chute is up, and the arms are raised, the arms will close almost all the way but the wheel shaft will put pressure on the chute top rail. It may cause failures to eject and if we try to lower the chute with the arm up, then things will get broken.

2019-02-12
Declan Freeman-Gleason11:09 PM

@Dana Batali Update on my work over our time off:

- There is now code to automatically determine the moment of inertia. This has been done on chassis 1. There might be a small issue with this, and I have no idea if the number is right, but it worked well enough.
- There is now code to determine effective wheelbase radius. This has been done on chassis 1.
- Characterization code now uses some tricks from Oblarg’s Python characterization script. Results are as good as the characterization script now (it seems). Units have been fixed for the characterization script.
- Subsystems fully shut themselves off on missing hardware instead of spewing. This should probably be turned off during competition.
- Superstructure is all set up to dynamically generate/follow paths from vision, and it also does stuff like automatic backing out and quick turning on hatch placement.
- Turn to heading in position mode had been finished, fixed, and tested.
- Ramsete controller is sort of tuned?
- Chassis 1 has been characterized well enough that we have negligible velocity error without a PID controller running.
- Encoder issues have been fixed with tape, drive friction is fixed with battery movement.

The result of this is: dynamic path planning reaches a goal with ~0-1 inch (x and y) and 0-2° of error in most reasonable paths (more challenging paths seem to have ~2 more inches of error). I’m quite surprised how well this works.

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:13 PM

Also, the CAN probe is broken for the Talons (not PCMs though) because of something CTRE did. I have a sort of jank solution for checking if a Talon is there, but we should look into a proper solution for this.

2019-02-13
Dana Batali8:38 AM

wow! we should have more snow days! Amazing progress! I'm curious what you mean by negligible velocity error without a PID controller... Are you running on the ground? Are you running in PctVbus mode? Are any forces being applied (ie are you turning or accelerating?). Or perhaps you mean no path-planning-PID? (ie: feedforward-only controller?)

Dana Batali8:39 AM

Another question: what sort of scrub factor did you compute? How different from .6ish?

Dana Batali8:42 AM

as for the can probe - happy to help, but curious what broke. Our implementation was already pretty "can-bussy", irrc

Dana Batali8:49 AM

also: just noticed the differnces between Ks for left and right. Surprisingly large.

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:55 AM

1. Running the Talon using only feedforward (e.g. `set(ControlMode.PercentOutput, 0, ControlMode.ArbitraryFeedforward, whatever)`) got the Talon very, very close to the target velocity on a straight path. It was slightly worse turning.
2. The scrub factor I computed was 1.202! Quite different. I though about this and asked some people, and I think this number makes sense.
3. The probe doesn’t seem to find Talons. There are a variety of possible sources for this issue, but I think that CTRE has changed a magic number on us. If you look in the probe, we use 0x02041400 (a message ID) to discover Talons. I also recall reading about this changing on some Chief Delphi post (which I can no longer find :whitefrowningface:).

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:00 AM

This is the post I was thinking of: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/how-to-detect-missing-canbus-or-attached-device-to-prevent-crash/343045/19>

Dana Batali9:05 AM

while searching this out, i ran into this release note:

Talon SRX / Victor SPX Firmware (4.15)

A critical fix has been applied to the Talon SRX and Victor SPX firmware for those of you using the firmware
closed-loop features. We’ve identified a circumstance where measurement noise can occur in the sensor velocity
and closed-loop derivative error, when motor output is less-than-full, and the current-draw measurement is nonzero
and changing

looks like an alternative would be to diagnose from our driverstation via:
`http://10.49.15.2:1250/?action=getdevices>`

Chris Rininger10:59 PM

One of the things Paul mentioned for losing weight is changing from CIMs to 775pros on the drivetrain. It would be good for someone to research the full implications of doing this given it is far easier to "smoke" 775pros than CIMs. I seem to recall there is a practice of limiting the voltage/current under some circumstances in order to avoid burning out 775pros in a drivetrain.

2019-02-15
Dana Batali8:05 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleasonmay opine differently than i on this, but if we change driver motors now, we'll be set back by days, needing to re-characterize the transmission. Also: there may be implications on the gearing ratios since, iirc, they have a different free-running rpm

Mark Tarlton12:09 PM

I noticed a couple of things in the deliverables document above. First, in the "Cargo Intake" there's a comment about "Anything that moves the arm must also move the chute pistons to the opposite position." That isn't quite correct because if the chute is down, the arm can be moved up and down without problem. A more accurate description is "Before moving chute up, make sure the arm is down. And before moving arm up, make sure chute is down."

Mark Tarlton12:10 PM

Also, the "SHOOTROCKET" and "SHOOTBAY" buttons seem to be reversed. for rocket, the chute is in the down position, and for the cargo ship, the chute must be in the up position

Apparently there is an unreleased RIO (image 14) and Update Suite Update (they go along with WPILib 2019.3.2) that fixes intermittent dropouts that many teams have been experiencing. We should watch for it to come out.

Binnur Alkazily8:26 PM

@Justice James pls check w/ @Mark Tarlton The chute not working for the cargo ship is due to the system shooting before the chute piston is fully extracted — we’ll need to add a small timer between extracting the piston and starting the belt to shoot the cargo

2019-02-20
Declan Freeman-Gleason2:27 PM

List of things I would like to try with vision/dynamic path planning (and have done by the end of next week):
1. Measure if odometry is correct.
2. Try adding/removing points from solvePNP.
3. (More of a question) If we use the tape’s corners, don’t the hatch panels occlude the lower tape corners? Do we have a fix for this?
4. Get a mode together that outputs the target’s field angle, so we can drive to it with a PID that controls wheel differential (Or maybe angular velocity, which we generate a feedforward from and then send to the wheel velocity controllers? This is sort of a cascading controller.)

Dana Batali3:18 PM

1. good idea, repeatedly correct even better
2. not sure what you mean by adding points to solvePNP. It's sorta fundamentally a 6pt-to-6pt mapping, but if you have evidence that it's not accurate, we could pass all 8 points.
3. i may have missed this.. If true we'll need to pick a different set of 6 (or more points)
4. This is something @Darwin Clark should try to do right? I believe his "rect" layer could output offsets to the target midpoint in "field coords".

Mark Tarlton7:56 PM

<#C16TUV48N|programming> -- there's a discussion in the <#CFKGVEY7Q|hatchteam> channel regarding damage to the robot that occurs when we go to the loading bay or to the cargo ship too fast. In those cases, the hatch end of the robot is approaching the game walls, and because there's an opening for the bumpers to slide into, if the driver overshoots the approach, we end up banging into the walls with things other than our bumpers. How feasible is it to use a distance sensor at the hatch end of the robot to minimize collisions with walls?

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:08 PM

Although the proposed programming fix is possible, and not even that difficult to initially implement (although reliability might be questionable), you should really just design your mechanism to be robust to collisions.

We should be prepared to run into things. I would only do this as a last resort.

Mark Tarlton8:12 PM

Normally, bumpers are the protection against collisions. However, these are special cases and it's related to accurately positioning the robot at target destinations which is why I asked.

Mark Tarlton8:18 PM

One of the things we've talked about throughout build season is how valuable it would be for the robot to handle the final approach to the transfer points. I think accurately landing the robot at a destination is a core concern. Both velocity and position need to be handled.

2019-02-21
Binnur Alkazily7:39 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason, I can assure you Mark already knows this: “you should really just design your mechanism to be robust to collisions“. The issue he is bringing up is a result of other decisions that was made earlier in the season and he is looking for workable options so that Spartronics robot will not just get thrashed at its first match.

Mark — we can wire up the distance sensor to a loop that stops the robot, but I think that will result in unintended consequences. I think the likely solution is the vision & motion planning which is implemented to help address your last point on landing robot accurately at a destination. But I haven’t seen anything beyond Darwin’s handheld target to even judge how well this works for game piece delivery. With that, driver can still slam into the field pieces, which as I recall was the intent when we designed the robot strategy… Suggested next step is to add the reflective tape to the rocket/ship and see how the vision+motion planning delivers a game piece.

Mark Tarlton8:27 AM

Thanks Binnur. I am working to move stuff out of harms way rather than add more reinforcing structure. I really believe that good vision and navigation can have a big impact (or a lesser impact :slightlysmilingface: ) on robot performance and on robot health. Go Programmers!

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:59 AM

Sorry, I see that that sentiment isn’t really helpful… As I said in my previous message it should be relatively quick to add, but we’ll need to mount and wire the sensors and ensure we have the correct hardware.

Dana Batali10:33 AM

Not sure if I'm stating the obvious but:

If the Robot IMU heading is reasonably stable, the vision can simply add its heading offset to target and post that value to as a target "global" angle. Now we just need a PID that tracks IMU Target angle based on the Robot IMU. In other words: the setpoint is the TargetIMU and the error term is (currentHeading - target).

Ideally we'll correct for heading in the inner control loop while approaching the target. I believe that limelight had some (trivial) example code that walked and chewed gum at the same time.

Finally: @Declan Freeman-Gleason do you have access to a robot chassis?

Mark Tarlton12:32 PM

Thanks Declan. My priorities are driving performance and robot safety -- pretty much in that order. We recently added an ultrasonic sensor to the back of the robot but I don't know if it sensed the hatch panel or the walls. I can find a good location if we need to add a different sensor for walls.

2019-02-22
Declan Freeman-Gleason1:25 PM

The PID approach makes sense to me… I would also like to try the cascading PID approach if we have time. I do not have access to a robot chassis until Monday as far as I know (I’ll be back late today, so I am available to meet tomorrow and Sunday if we think that would be helpful).

Declan Freeman-Gleason1:28 PM

@Mark Tarlton Do you have a model number/data sheet for that sensor?

As for a scheme to stop collisions, do you think it just makes sense to put on the brakes immediately after we’re too close? Are there any times we wouldn’t want to stop (I can’t think of any).

Also, are we planning to use the design we had on bag day, or are we considering others in robot reveals like the “captain hook” idea?

Darwin Clark1:35 PM

1. :+1: , and this is related to what we were seeing where the target pose was not equal to the current pose, do I have that right?
2. Out of curiosity, how many points can we pass @Dana Batali? If we wanted (given it may be unreasonable...) could we pass each corner + center of the rectangles? (Totaling 5 points per rectangle)
3. Looking at fig 4-32 in the manual, it looks like the bottom two corners would be covered by a hatch... Its probable that even with the covering two rectangles would be identified (Less 'height' but same 'width'), however the current PNP model would be inaccurate... Perhaps we could make a 2nd PNP model for the covered rectangles if this turns out to be a problem? (Then decide which one to use based on ratio of height to width of rectangle)
4. :+1: , this is doable on my end.

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:00 PM

As expected, a full update of the RIO that fixes the FPGA watchdog issues/periodic disabling has been released as 2019_v14. This goes along with NI update suite 2019.2.0. I thought we would have to update WPILib too, but I see no mention of that. Might as well anyway.

This RIO image update is required by rules update 14: https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2019/Manual/TeamUpdates/TeamUpdate14.pdf?fbclid=IwAR1lq7ShLfmxJE-huXUlD7-jyr-qVJW4g9mxKBBWzC4r8C36QyEkYVkyKm8>

We will have to do this on (at least) the main robot.

Mark Tarlton2:02 PM

@Riyadth Al-Kazily may have more info on the ultrasonic sensor. I just saw Kenneth installing it.

It's really only at the loading station and cargo ship that we can't count on bumpers to cushion the impact. If we know that we're close to one of those destinations, then we can enable crash avoidance / parking assist.

Times where we might want to crash intentionally is playing defense. Those impacts are hard on our robot as well, though.

But for me, collision avoidance is really part of the bigger problem of efficiently and accurately landing the robot at key destinations. Asking a driver to consistently do that given the limitations of video seems to be asking a lot. Do we have a scheme for landing the robot at points like the loading station or the ships in general? I remember that Dana was thinking about using the stripes on the floor to guide us in. I thought the retro-reflective markers would be great for doing this but I now know this isn't in the plan.

For hatch handling, I'm looking for a more secure grab of the panels. Placing them at the rocket means we have to get them out past our bumpers. I'd prefer having a good hold on them until they're in place, but ...

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:04 PM

We hope to use vision (with the retroreflective strips) and (potentially) dynamic path planning to align with scoring targets. @Darwin Clark has a video of this, I think.

Riyadth Al-Kazily2:20 PM

Regarding the ultrasonic sensor, I do not know the model number. @Peter Hall @Kenneth Wiersema ?
Also note that the sensor is mounted where the hatch panel holes are, so they won’t let you see cargo ship walls for example. And when carrying a hatch the sensor is covered.

Binnur Alkazily3:20 PM

So, be mindful when you decide to hit the breaks :wink: Doesn’t sound like a viable crash avoidance solution…

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:58 PM

A better scheme might be to slow subtly as we get close, eventually reaching a full stop

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:22 PM

@Darwin Clark Can you have number 4 ready by Monday? Put the field relative heading to `/SmartDashboard/Vision/Reverse/fieldHeading`, and get robot heading from `/SmartDashboard/Drive/imuHeading`

Also, some questions:

I went reading this (https://github.com/Team-2502/Vision2019>) team’s vision code (they claim to be driving to targets like we want to), and I see that they’re using subpixel corner coords, and RANSAC. I have heard from some that subpixel corners yielded worse results, but that makes me wonder if we’ve tested subpixel corners/if you have an opinion. My second question is if we’ve tested performance with RANSAC/if you have an opinion on that.

Mark Tarlton10:01 PM

There's obviously tension between performance and safety. Another option is to have a distance vs. max safe velocity table. This would result in gradual slowing that's still very aggressive but with a safety margin built it. It requires data about deceleration rates and stopping distances.

2019-02-23
Dana Batali9:34 AM

two points on #4
1. we need to make sure we get maximal framerate since it'll be in the inner loop of a PID: a) perform a flush after send b) work at lowest reasonable res c) make sure no print statements or extra diagnostics get in the way.
2. we can also provide another error metric for distance trivially: a) first we measure in pixels the height of a target from the view of a vision cam at the target (ie 6" away). b) now we measure the height of the current target and subtract one from another. This is a "distance error" metric that can be fed to the VisionTargetManager for its approach.

Make sense?

Dana Batali9:35 AM

and regarding concerns wrt PNP: i have yet to see conclusive proof that we're getting invalid or sufficiently innacurate answers out of our current solution. I would think any time spent on PNP should first be spent on trying to characterize its accuracy...

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:57 AM

Makes sense. How would you use height error to inform the drivetrain? Maybe it can scale linear velocity?

Dana Batali10:48 AM

good question! when height error is zero we're at the target. When height error is "large" we want to go fast-ish. When it's small we want to go slowish. If we're running in velocity-control mode, then your idea sounds quite reasonable. Seems plausible that a "non-linear" mapping like i described will have some desirable properties.

2019-02-24
Dana Batali10:08 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason @Jeffrey Tappen: here's an alternative to "ternary hell":

https://github.com/dbadb/2019-DeepSpace/blob/master/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/frc2019/Constants.java>

two ingredients:

1. inspect an optional file on the robot, "~/machineid" for a string that characterizes a constant variant state (like TestChassis)
2. a magic method name, `Constants.static()`, in which we can place checks for different configs and block all the changes together.

Now we can support more than two variants and even different year's robots.
Upon request, I can either submit or do a pull request. It's perfectly fine if you have other fish to fry.

If want to go with this, we should also make tiny mods to Drive.java

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:00 PM

@Dana Batali @Darwin Clark I just realized that it will be a little tricky to do latency compensation on the target's height. If we send the "processing time" like we do with solvePNP, and roughly know the location of the target then we could use the robot state map and some trig to figure out what the height of the target is after some movement. Do we think that's worth it?

Dana Batali3:26 PM

top of the head response: if you truly trust your odometry then you don't really need vision. If you want to eliminate computations related to latency, then just use fast vision in the inner loop. To minimize complexity we don't really need any trig or distance calculations, just a measure of error. This is the dead-simple solution and we should try it before adding more complexity.

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:28 PM

I agree

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:39 PM

That seems reasonable. We should have Jeffrey integrate that tomorrow.

Enrique Chee6:50 PM

Cruz Strom7:46 PM

There is room on the robot cart with the mobil toolbox to store the bag.

Darwin Clark9:44 PM

@Dana Batali I spent some time today tuning the vision system for the hallway outside of Chee's room, and I noticed some irregularities in the 'X point' reported from solvePNP. I had done a fresh wipe of the code on the Pi, replacing it with the up-to-date repository code (standard procedure for updating the Pi) and the numbers reported when tuning triggered some red flags. Lateral reports ('Y point') were approximate correct (Accurate to about 2 in.), and I did not validate theta reports. The algorithm seemed to be consistantly underestimating the X value, and the error got worse the farther the target was away. For reference: 13 inches away was reporting 10in, 40 inches away was reporting 30 inches, and 90 inches away was reporting 70inches. These measurements were validated with a tape measure (and sad caveman eyeballs). This is particularly concerning because nothing was changed from bag day to today, excepting only the change of mounting (black Amazon case to a 3d printed case), leading me to believe it was an unintended software change that might be causing these irregularities. On Tuesday I'll clean up a lot of messy areas in the code, so we have a clean area to start debugging Wednesday.

2019-02-26
Binnur Alkazily8:00 AM

Discussion thread on bandwidth limits for matches, maybe an interest https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/fms-how-does-it-handle-4-0-mb-bandwidth-cap-for-camera-streaming/348231/9>

2019-02-27
Dana Batali10:08 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason @Jeffrey Tappen i think i see a bug in DifferentialDriveDynamicsConstraint.java

Dana Batali10:09 AM


public double getMaxVelocity(S state)
{
return Units.meterstoinches(
drive.getMaxAbsVelocity(
Units.meterstoinches(state.getCurvature()),
// Curvature is in inverse inches
absvoltagelimit));
}


should be:


return Units.meterstoinches(
drive.getMaxAbsVelocity(
Units.inchestometers(state.getCurvature()),
absvoltagelimit));

notice that the correct conversion is made in MinMaxAccel

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:28 AM

Wow! Good catch... I can't see how this would be correct, so we should fix it. Right?

Dana Batali10:59 AM

yes - we should fix it. Hopefully the change will have a positive effect :wink:

2019-03-02
Dana Batali4:55 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: does this look fishy to you (from DCTransmission.java):


public double freespeedatvoltage(final double voltage)
{
if (voltage > Util.kEpsilon)
{
return Math.max(0.0, voltage - frictionvoltage()) speedpervolt();
}
else if (voltage < Util.kEpsilon)
{
return Math.min(0.0, voltage + frictionvoltage()) speedper_volt();
}
else
{
return 0.0;
}
}

Dana Batali4:56 PM

(are they trying to handle negative voltages? - if so it doesn't look right). the 0 case only occurs if voltage == kEpsilon

Dana Batali4:58 PM

so perhaps it should be:

if(voltage < -Util.kEpsilon)

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:02 PM

That seems correct to me. I don’t see why you would add while the voltage is still positive.

Do you think we should test a path or two with and without these changes, or just apply them and move on?

Dana Batali5:23 PM

i'm pretty confident we can just apply and move on

Declan Freeman-Gleason6:03 PM

Just being cautious (but you’re right, this seems like it can’t be correct).

As for the issue at the top of this thread, what they have (at a second glance) seems correct if curvature is in inverse inches. Have you discovered that it isn’t (it is usually defined like that, right)? Thoughts?

Declan Freeman-Gleason6:19 PM

Just FYI, (if I remember correctly) two simultaneous streams took ~2 mbps for us. I don’t remember the resolution. We’re in a good place as a result of h.264 in terms of bandwidth usage, now we just need to worry about camera reliability.

Dana Batali6:51 PM

all the drive calcs are in meters after which they are converted to inches

Dana Batali6:58 PM

(unless you see some conversions within drive that I may have missed)

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:24 PM

I’m pretty sure that the velocity, acceleration, and curvature of each `Pose2dWithCurvature` are in inches. `state.getCurvature()` would then be in in^-1. You are correct that `DifferentialDrive` uses meters, but it seemed you were advocating changing the conversion on units coming out of `state`, not `_drive`.

Dana Batali10:37 PM

We can discuss tomorrow... I'm not sure where the misunderstanding is in my original post

2019-03-03
Dana Batali10:23 AM

to close this thread: 1.declan convinces me that the the curvature conversion is correct ,but that it could be renamed to inverseinches to inversemeters. Rather than that, a comment was added to clarify the situation which reduces to `1/in * in/m => 1/m`.
2. the -kEpsilon is definitely a bug but not a very consequential one. It should be no risk to make this change.

Dana Batali2:35 PM

Dana Batali2:36 PM

also, it appears that all the command-line args are no longer used to express camera configs. Probably a good idea to get rid of them?

Dana Batali2:39 PM

ideally the initial value will be accurate and this update question is void. Last we looked, a correct estimate at one point might lead to an incorrect one later. So it would be quite amusing to watch (but hardly useful at this point, apparently). At the point we get globally valid values, then we can consider the benefits of the updates.

Which reminds me: should we be sending "null" targets when we don't have one? Are you timestamping the targets you receive so you don't use stale ones?

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:43 PM

I am timestamping the targets. Speaking of which, are we setting the “time it took to process the frame” field for latency compensation, or do we still set it to 0?

Dana Batali2:43 PM

last i looked we provide and estimate of how stale (in ms?)

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:56 PM

Good to know. The code currently assumes seconds, so that should probably be fixed.

Dana Batali3:23 PM

looks like seconds since we're using python time.monotonic

Darwin Clark3:33 PM

@Dana Batali Thanks for the catch of logtest.txt... That was residue from when I was adding the logging handlers, it should be pointing at the /tmp file. I suppose we would have to have a discussion about the intended use case of the command line aguments... When tuning / debugging I don't personally use them, but I can see an argument for keeping them to assist with debugging.

Dana Batali3:37 PM

also: i see that the exposure_mode is still fireworks. Can you explain to me why it's not "off"?

Dana Batali3:39 PM

perhaps it's only valid if awb_mode is "auto"?

Darwin Clark3:42 PM

Whoops; it shouldn't be fireworks. The only reason it was ever fireworks was because on the listed expose modes (don't have the URL on hand) it fit our needs quite well, but we have sense been using ISO (with success) to do the same job as 'firworks' expose mode.

Darwin Clark9:54 PM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason Just a heads up about the heightError + angleOffset solution. I just checked in a version that is more-or-less ready to test on Wendsday (Ideally, I would like to get some more reasonable measurements for the height offset). Two things for clarifcation: the values are going to be under the same NT key, however the end of the key (normally '/solvePNP') is going to be '/heading'. The format will be (degree offset, height error, delta time). Secondly, the degree offset currently being posted is simply the offset relative to the Pi frame(left being a negative offset, right being a positive offset), you mentioned looking at the IMU value in NT, but I held off on that untill we touch base.

thread on video stream problems

Dana Batali7:19 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason @Darwin Clark :

• can we set up a replica of FMS at home to debug the situation?

• remove the google stun server in dashboard, webRTCsignaling.js, line 70.

Dana Batali7:22 AM

if this doesn't work onto the mitigation:

• are you using uv4l mjpeg server or frcvision?
• are you using our dashboard or frcvision?
• if our dashboard, are you using videostream or camera widget. I ask this because we probably can't afford two simultaneous mjpeg streams. I'm happy to make some mods so it shuts down mjpeg streams when camera switching.
• if using mjpegstreams and there is browser instability, we might want to move back to firefox (at least for the videofeed window)

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:33 AM

We are just using the webpage, not the dashboard.

Dana Batali7:33 AM

notes on uv4l mjpeg streamer:

1. jpegquality of 4 (yes 4/100) at 640x480 consumed 2Mb-ish. Quality of 8 is 5.5mb
2. jpg quality 10 at 320x240 is 2.5Mb

Dana Batali7:34 AM

so you current have no camera switching?

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:34 AM

Yes

Dana Batali7:34 AM

how much bandwidth are you using?

Dana Batali7:34 AM

Dana Batali7:34 AM

Dana Batali7:35 AM

(and you could have camera switching)

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:37 AM

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:38 AM

Dana Batali7:40 AM

Dana Batali7:41 AM

Dana Batali7:43 AM

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:44 AM

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:11 AM

@Dana Batali The error we got from uv4l when trying to stream mjpeg or h.264 on the field was something like “streaming to another client”.

Dana Batali8:32 AM

`Device is already in use for streaming by another process?`

Dana Batali8:34 AM

(that process was probably the multicamera server, can't have both running at the same time, with /dev/video0 opened). Remedy is to make sure the process isn't running nor "installed", sudo rm /dev/video*, reboot

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:35 AM

What’s strange is that this doesn’t appear off the field. It was not “use by another process”, but “streaming to something else”.

Dana Batali8:38 AM

did a strings on uv4l looking for "another" and only got one hit

Dana Batali8:42 AM


An error occurred while streaming:
An unkown error occurred while streaming
Device is already in use for streaming by process PID=
Device is already in use for streaming by another process
enable the streaming server. Possible values are: 'auto' (tentatively start the server), 'required' (exit if failing to start the server, only works if --foreground is enabled), 'off' (no server at all).
- to run the 'raspicam' driver with the streaming server enabled on port 9000:
- to run the streaming server on port 9000 and attach it to a given video

Dana Batali8:44 AM

i guess this (uv4l/mjpg) is of some interest because the quality/bandwidth control settings provided by the frcvision approach are barely useful.

Dana Batali8:55 AM

more on FMS:

UDP/TCP 1180 - 1190: Camera Data
TCP 1735: SmartDashboard
UDP 1130: DS-to-Robot control data
UDP 1140: Robot-to-DS status data
HTTP 80: Camera/web interface
HTTP 443: Camera/web interface (secure)
UDP/TCP 554: Real-Time Streaming Protocol for h.264 camera streaming
UDP/TCP 5800-5810: Team Use
Teams are permitted to utilize ports 5800-5810 for their own purposes, or any other open ports (other than 1130 and 1140) if not already allocated.

Dana Batali9:19 AM

so any other open unallocated ports are legit

2019-03-11
Declan Freeman-Gleason12:30 PM

I think this was a uv4l issue, not a WebRTC issue. We could access the uv4l page, but we could not initiate a WebRTC or MJPEG stream. Both complained that someone was already streaming (not that the video device was already in use). Options:
1. We could set up a WebRTC streamer using something like https://github.com/mpromonet/webrtc-streamer> (which also provides a convenient JavaScript library), or even use ffmpeg and GStreamer.
2. We could also try to simulate the FMS and figure out what the problem is with uv4l.

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:42 PM

@Dana Batali I'm going to start a thread on a concerning issue with dynamic spline parameterization we had during the competition.

Basically, we dynamically generated a "backup 4 in" trajectory before shooting in the cargo bay (I did this dynamically because it was more convenient to write and made it easy to preserve our odometry pose). This would sometimes cause either a stack overflow (we only saw a print of "StackOverflowException" once though), or exhaustion of the heap (It said `realloc` failed before a jvm crash, which is usally because you're trying to resize a memory block but don't have any memory left.) This is strange for a couple of reasons: this works fine for pregenerated splines, and the number of spline subdivisions should be the same because the splines are the same length (i.e. the arcs should all have the same dx, dy, and dtheta). Perhaps the dynamic paths have malformed waypoints in some situations? We saw this issue once during testing (when the code printed "at com.spartronics4915.lib.spline.SplineGenerator:86" over and over, but we just hoped it had to do with some weird electrical issues).

My fix for this was to just generate the spline at the beginning of the match (because we've never had issues with that) and just reset the odometry. You can see it here: https://github.com/Spartronics4915/2019-DeepSpace/commit/b35e51b0644ecf6dbb364e5ade8f018d55b117cf#diff-94bcd8e2bb480ad8689ad4c0a930c096R366>. Obviously this isn't optimal, and we will need to fix this if we need to do any real dynamic generation (e.g. for vision).

Dana Batali1:25 PM

too bad we don't have the exact text for the message or more helpful diagnostics like:

1. did you ssh in to the raspi and look at /dev/video*
2. could you duplicate it on the test field?
3. running a traceroute from raspi to driver station ip would be interesting
4. also sudo fuser /dev/video[0,1,..] would show which process has the video file open.
5. did you try to eliminate the the stun server line as I requested?

I've looked into a variety of solutions and all were pretty hacky/convoluted. Only the uv4l was even approximately simple.

My reading of the ffmpeg was that the latency was pretty high. So I think our goal is to rely on the h264 encoder running on the the raspi gpu (and built-in to the picam interface). The other part of the goal is to tie into standard web tech and I think that means webrtc. Finding the combination of both is interesting.

Here's one that uses raw picam output and bypasses webrtc by decoding h264 in javascript (via emscripten):

https://github.com/131/h264-live-player>

Here's more on a gstreamer solution but I'm not sure we can connect it to a browser. Rather may need to have a custom app to display the pixels:

https://raspberrypi.stackexchange.com/questions/68251/gstreamer-full-hd-video-rtp-stream-on-raspberry-pi>

Dana Batali1:27 PM

the webrtc-streamer might be worth looking into, but relies on v4l2 which doesn't appear to be tightly integrated/supported by picam

Dana Batali2:33 PM

so i just got the webrtc-streamer up and limping.

Good news so far:
• it's open source
• it relies only on v4l2 (and not uv4l which is closed source)
• there are lots of diagnostic messages going by that may be helpful if we continue to have problems
• at a bitrate of 2000mbit, i get similar quality and latency to our u4vl solution (but i haven't done rigorous latency checks)

Bad-news so far:

• CPU usage is near 100% of a core for a single feed. uv4l is much less (which implies to me that we're not using the gpu encoder, so I may need to figure that out).
• i haven't yet figured out out to configure max bitrates, etc.

Dana Batali2:40 PM

since it relies on v4l2, its interface is similar to what we get from frcvision:


pi@dbvision(rw):~/webrtc/html$ v4l2-ctl -l

Dana Batali3:04 PM

few things to consider:

• if we're running out of mem, it seems that someone must be holding a reference to the voluminous path data. Have you any theories on this?
• if you run your path in feedforward-only mode, is it possible you don't need to reset odometry or regen the path?
• since its such a trivial path it's also plausible that we should just use position control-mode (with a setpoint of -6,-6. A little fancier and we could look into a custom motion profile.

Dana Batali4:02 PM

looking at this: com.spartronics4915.lib.spline.SplineGenerator:86

we can see that we're in a recursive split procedure of the spline. It does seem that this could be the source of an infinite recursion (rather than a memory leak).

here's the condition: `twist.dy > maxDy || twist.dx > maxDx || twist.dtheta > maxDTheta`

it's possible we should add a recursion depth check to limit the number of subdivisions and print the conditions at that point

Dana Batali4:03 PM

(something isn't converging with the subdivision which may point to an issue with the input curve, but still it won't hurt to add a recursion depth limit)

Declan Freeman-Gleason4:27 PM

Yeah, a recursion limit was the first thing at the competition that I considered, but I didn’t have time to figure out a reasonable limit. I also wasn’t sure what we should do when we hit that limit (just throw an exception?) I should have been clearer that I thought that was the issue. The reason I mentioned memory was because of the `realloc` thing. My most reasonable explanation for this is that sometimes when we do too many recursions we allocate enough objects to exhaust the heap before we eat through the stack.

I’ve looked at the condition at the heart of this bug for a while yesterday and today, and it seems to me that two splines of equal length and shape should have the same number of segments. Am I misunderstanding `Twist2d`?

Dana Batali4:41 PM

twist2d.dx is the length of the arc and each iteration should produce a smaller one... twist2d.dtheta is the change of curvature and should converge to 0 with each iteration twist2d.dy relates to the current heading at a point. If the initial heading computation / specification is borked, this should be related to the problem. If the problem is with the spline, then we should be able to build a regression test that captures the bogus condition. All this can be done without robot access which is a good thing. As for what a reasonable limit would be, my intuition says 10 is quite a few, 5 may even be a lot (that's 32 subintervals that are represented by a partial circle). And when you hit the limit, it's probably fine just to go to the alternate condition which is just to add the initial point of the spline (with curvature) to the output.

Dana Batali4:42 PM

so a regression test could be added that passed a variety of potential bogus inputs and see what happens.

Dana Batali4:48 PM

i'm guessing for a straight curve, there's some condition where the values of twist produce either NaN or Infinity and then we'll never terminate

2019-03-12
Dana Batali8:24 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: a couple more items to chew on:

• splines are useful to generate elegant curves, yet for this case we have a short straight line. This suggests that all the spline tech is overkill. First we optimize curvature, then we resample at equidistant points, then we apply timing contraints. It occurs to me we can bypass splines entirely, you can sample your line and just proceeed straight to the timing-contraint phase.
•here's an alternate but similar take: the spline resampler is driven by maxDx for this straight-line case. My recollection is that maxDx is 2 inches. For a 4 inch line, you effectively only have 3 samples. And that's the input to the timing constraints. Given all this, you could bypass all the constraint machinery and go directly to timed samples which is the input to path follower.

Thoughts?

Dana Batali10:56 AM

fyi: just roughed-in a new method for two-point path generation. Not tested on a real robot, but unit-test output looks good for the simple linear-fwd/rev inputs. We could add a few more tests to the suite to see about 2-point arcs.

When the switch was unplugged from the radio, the roborio Comm LED when off. Does this indicate an error? Could it be related to the loss of connection problems we kept seeing?

Dana Batali1:46 PM

https://webrtchacks.com/an-intro-to-webrtcs-natfirewall-problem/>

one theory: (depends on murky understanding of FMS/vlan)...

1. we establish a connection to camera
2. we negotiate a stream (say udp)
3. stream-server starts "broadcasting",
4. vlan filters udp packets - server thinks it's broadcasting, client sees nada

2019-03-17
Darwin Clark6:06 PM

@Dana Batali I'm late to the party...But here's a psudo-complete symptom list of the camera problems, and the order in which they occured:
1. Off of the FMS, everything works exactly like it would back at the robotics shop (this was Friday in the pits)
2. Fwiw, before the first practice match Cruz and I were on the main field for vision tuning, and the vision mjpg stream was working properly. (This data point is probabbly irrelevent, because the radio was un-flashed, and I was connecting in exactly the same way I would at the robotics shop)
3. At the first few practice matches, I went on as technician to validate the cameras were working, and I was experiencing behavior were I would select the video stream in the Dashboard, and no feed would show up. On the fame in only said the name of the stream (front/back) and a -1 where a time normally is.
4. In the pits between the end of those matches and opening ceremony, I tethered to the robot with the driver station, and the cameras began to work again.
5. During the next match, instead of using the dashboard camera stream viewer, I tried navigating directly to the uv4l server (notably on port 8080). It was at this time when I realised the port limitations put into place by the fms, and I changed the webserver port to 1180
6. Connecting to the webserver at port 1180 worked fine on FMS, however when selecting 'two way audio/video' or 'MJPG stream' It would give an error similar to 'device is streaming to another client'. The errors were different between the two, but had the same gist (streaming to another client)
7. After the 'streaming to another client' message, I changed the camera IP in the driver station, thinking it might be hogging some ghost connection and confusing Uv4l, this also did not fix the issue.
8. Finally, I gave up with uv4l, and told the frcvision web dashboard to run the 'multiCameraServer', and connected to that on the driver station, which worked find. (The quality was horrendously low, and only worked well as an alignment camera)

A few things I should have tried in retrospect:
• Remove STUN line in dashboard
• Try setting the uv4l webserver port to the dedicated h.264 port on the FMS

Dana Batali8:12 PM

@Darwin Clark - this is all great data. I will continue to digest and we can plan to discuss tomorrow.

In the future it would be good to do the braindump immediately after the competition (or even between matches). I understand that after the huge energies required to even manage the crises, that it's very difficult to muster the extra energy required to "jot it all down"... Still "jot it all down and share" you must! :slightlysmilingface:.

Specific points: the FMS port for h264 is not likely to be the problem, since it's really just a misnamed "rtsp" port (that can carry h264). We have no intentions to use the rtsp port since the default configuration specifies a 2sec latency.

I've been dabbling with non-webrtc and non-rtsp h264 feeds. It's looking like it may be a reasonable choice (search for h264-live-player) since it only involves tcp (and not udp) and doesn't rely on the very-complex negotiations associated with webrtc. We can discuss tomorrow, but it will involve a new raspi image and I'm still working out "robustness".

I validated a new raspi image (based on the rev-3 version of the FRCvision alluded to elsewhere). Seemed to run fine on today's tests.

On the vision front: @Declan Freeman-Gleason and I were saddened to learn that no camera matrix ("couch", '"theory", "default') delivered accurate results. I will need to spend some time re-validating the results from my cameras and if they do validate, I would have to cast the blame on the brand/version of the cameras installed on the robot. Other than saying: "use mine", we'll be in an awkward state.

We did have a few issues getting vision and camera feeds to work on the 2nd robot:

1. the vision cam had a connectivity issue (loose ribbon-cable). This was time-consuming to debug. It was also mounted differently than the code checked in. The new config.py file made it easy to change the flipping.
2. @Declan Freeman-Gleason had an issue with the front cam (iirc) and this turned out to be due to the fact that it wasn't plugged into the hub. Another thing to add to your checklist.
3. bringing up a new raspi image wasn't all-that-difficult as long as you have a nice pair of pliers (to pull and plug sdcards). I did drop one into the chassis and that cost us 10minutes before eagle-eyes-declan could rescue it. We were able to connect via "frcvision.local", then change to static IP, establish the correct "vision-app" settings, etc.

Dana Batali2:49 PM

the big gotcha in the past has been access to enough camera bandwidth for a price comparable to the raspi. There we get the CSI cameras for $8-$25 and the one connector has been sufficient. Looking at the current state of affairs, a jetson might be able to drive 6 CSI cameras (2-3 would be nice for us), but the carrier boards are expensive and support for consumer-grade CSI cameras appears to be a "novel requirement" for the folks targeting industrial applications.

They also talk about using the picam plus lens so it seems that this board is maybe 2x the cost of raspi but more capable. I like the idea of starting with an off-the-shelf robot that can be used for development by an individual without requiring an entire shop and team for support.

2019-03-21
Dana Batali10:04 AM

@Mark Tarlton: what can you tell me about your fancy new multi-pi mount? What printer, how much time, CAD files? Looked pretty professional!

Dana Batali10:25 AM

@Darwin Clark: any luck with dbcam8 matrix last night?

Darwin Clark10:32 AM

@Dana Batali I wasn't able to run any vision stuff, we were correcting the out-of-focus driver cameras on robot. #1 (We've experienced this before once at CK, it's the behaivor where you have to rotate the lens to bring it back into focus)

Dana Batali10:34 AM

ah - priority makes sense! Thanks for the update

Mark Tarlton11:48 AM

It's a @Paul Vibrans design. I'll forward the .stl files via email. They were printed in PLA on various printers. it's probably 4-6 hours per enclosure total but I printed two of everything and printed them in 'draft' mode (0.25mm layer thickness) just so I could get them done before the meeting.

The enclosures consist of 4 pieces. The base holds three raspi boards with ethernet, and power USB sockets exposed plus access to the SD card. The cover has slots for the camera cables to come out plus additional vents. The Camera Base is a small frame that holds the picam board and can be tilted up or down. It's used for the driver cameras only and attaches to the outside of the cover pointed in opposite directions The cover screws on over the two driver cameras and shields them. The vision camera installs inside base and looks out through the center of the LED ring.

The raspi boards are mounted vertically with air vents in the bottom and top of the enclosure. power comes in on the top, Ethernet cables all come in through the same side and SD card slots are exposed on the opposite side. Slots in the top give ventilation per board plus room for the flat camera cables.

The cases are tapped for #6 screws for assembly.

Mark Tarlton12:29 PM

We also saved 5 oz of weight. The old enclosures and mounts were about 9 oz with a lot of weight coming from nuts and bolts. the new enclosure with screws is less than 4 oz

Justice James5:13 PM

I think that was an IR sensor problem. We re-tuned it in the last several minutes of unbag time, but it wouldn't hurt to check on Friday.

2019-03-22
Dana Batali11:14 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason newly detected bug in `SplineGenerator::getSegmentArc`

line 88 should be checking absolute values. Found this while debugging a trivial path from your test suite called "curvedTest". That curve produced large negative dy, which failed the test and the result was only two samples along the spline.


if (Math.abs(twist.dy) > maxDy ||
Math.abs(twist.dx) > maxDx ||
Math.abs(twist.dtheta) > maxDTheta

Dana Batali1:14 PM

new lidar tech: https://techcrunch.com/2019/03/22/gates-backed-lumotive-upends-lidar-conventions-using-metamaterials/>

Declan Freeman-Gleason3:45 PM

This actually explains some bugs I was seeing. That’s a good catch. I’ll commit a fix.

Dana Batali3:47 PM

one minor sug if you're in the file, Rather than have a static global for recursion, you can just pass a depth parameter. First invocation would set the param to 0. Primary benefit is that two threads would be able to execute the spline splitter simultaneously.

2019-04-03
Randy Groves1:10 PM

2019-04-09
Binnur Alkazily11:55 AM

I don’t see much written around embedded programmer… This one from Spotify is a good read
https://labs.spotify.com/2019/04/09/an-opinionated-anthropology-of-the-embedded-programmer-its-habits-and-habitat/>

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:16 PM

@Dana Batali @Darwin Clark @Jeffrey Tappen I want to start a thread regarding directions for advancement in programming over the next year. I think that the most useful thing we can develop is a robust localization capability (as opposed to continued work with individual vision target recognition). This area has some challenges that are universal, and some that are unique to FRC, but the general options (that I know of) for localization are as follows:
1. LIDAR based—use a (probably 2D to limit expense) LIDAR scanner to localize ourselves on a known map, or perform simultaneous mapping as well (the former is much preferred because of computational constraints, and we already know the map). From conversations with other teams, there is a variety existing software that solves this problem for many environments that is available to use (like Google Cartographer), but the small amount of good reflective material on the field limits the usefulness of this option for localization (gamepiece localization is a different story).
2. Camera based—use some type of camera to identify the offsets (accurately) of features in the scene. Match these features to a known map (you can build the map as you go, if you wish, but once again it's preferable to use a known map for efficiency purposes). For this option you can use a front-facing camera, or a ceiling-facing camera. I am partial to the camera option because good features are always available (especially for non-ceiling scenes), sensors are relatively inexpensive, and there are promising preexisting solutions to camera-based feature extraction, feature matching, and loop closing (which is a subset of feature matching).
a. I am especially interested in one specific localization solution using a camera-based approach called ORB-SLAM2 (https://webdiis.unizar.es/~raulmur/orbslam/>). With a set of stereo cameras or a single RGB-D (e.g. Intel RealSense) camera you can accurately localize yourself in world coordinates, and you can even pre-map an area and match to a previously made point cloud. The original ORB-SLAM paper specifically mentions that planar movement is supported, so a ceiling localization approach should work (although fields like Portland or Tacoma present challenges with their featureless ceilings). When I mentioned this Intel RealSense+ORB-SLAM2 approach to @Jeffrey Tappen, he said that his Dad mentioned this exact (!) solution to him. This makes me think I might not be so crazy.
b. The above approach seems cool, but presents some challenges/questions as well. Do you point at the ceiling, or just point forward like we do with current vision cameras? If you point forward, what happens when the robot is totally pointed towards the constantly moving crowd (just use encoder localization for that time)? If you do the ceiling, what happens with featureless ceilings/how many features are "enough"? How much computational power do we need for this approach? Should we go with a full-on ROS setup, or use ORB-SLAM2 standalone? What type of sensor fusion should we do (EKF, particle filter, none)? ROS provides many sensor fusion options.
3. Finally, what other options are there? I've mentioned two, but what about integrating position from IMU (XBot did this and fused the results), or other things like optical flow? How far should we go with sensor fusion? What else are we missing>

2019-04-10
Dana Batali1:29 PM

slam2 definitely looks interesting. As i understand it you can seed it with "key/salient points" and so it will work even when still. Better with 2 cameras in that case, but apparently still usable with only one (because motion gave it prior data). Still if we can point the camera in a direction where lots of robots don't interfere, that's likely to be more stable.

I recall @Jeffrey Tappen's dad indicating he was comfortable with EKF. I'm certain that's fine but if we're starting from scratch, i think particle filters would be preferred since a) they handle non-linearities and b) they appear to be easier (or as-easy) to implement.

I still think ROS may be overkill on the grounds of learning curve and ongoing maintenance over multiple years.

One last point: SLAM2 relies on PNP (just sayin'...) :slightlysmilingface:

Dana Batali1:54 PM

https://medium.com/@deepanshut041/introduction-to-orb-oriented-fast-and-rotated-brief-4220e8ec40cf>

2019-04-14
Binnur Alkazily3:42 PM

2019-05-02
Dana Batali9:17 AM

Both seem very interesting/fun... I would be tempted to go for the T265 on the grounds that if it works, we'll have a much simpler pile of code to maintain. On the other side we could get deeper into SLAM tech if we go with the 435. That said: i have a free microsoft kinect that we could use for depth images if the 265 proves insufficient.


prices: T265: $199, D435: $179

Dana Batali9:20 AM

i suppose we could get both since we have a budget of $500. I suspect that would be overkill: we'll likely have our hands full playing with one of them. As a comparison a limelight is ~$400. These both appear to be a relative bargain compared to the limelight.

Dana Batali9:22 AM

found this in the 265 brochure:

An ideal operating environment for the T265 has a reasonable number of fixed, distinct visual features in view. It will perform poorly if the entire field of view contains moving, near field objects such as people. In cases where crowds are expected indoors, it is advised to point the camera upwards, where it can use features on the ceilings to navigate.

Dana Batali9:23 AM

here's the realsense developer site:

https://dev.intelrealsense.com/docs/api>

https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense>

Dana Batali9:34 AM

also noticed that the T265 is new and appears to have fewer docs.
Here's the C++ example to pull pose data off the 265:

https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/tree/master/examples/pose>

https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/blob/master/doc/t265.md>

2019-05-03
Darwin Clark7:42 PM

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhHvuAoFC6I> Interesting demo of the T265, driven through ROS. Something this makes me wonder: How much of the position is determined via IMU vs. the fish-eye camera?

2019-05-04
Dana Batali8:55 AM

Nice! And your musings are right on target: the amount to weigh the inputs of IMU and cameras is answered with statistics/probability. This is done via some variant of Monte Carlo Localization or Kalman Filters. http://www.probabilistic-robotics.org> is the "classic" (college) textbook on the subject. And here's a wikipedia source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_inference>

The 265 api accepts/requires odometry from the wheels which is another sensor source that is combined with IMU and camera. So the idea is that an estimate of accuracy is associated with each input source and these are weighed together according to the accuracy estimate (ie fused).

Darwin Clark9:45 PM

FYI, (@Declan Freeman-Gleason and @Dana Batali) The due date for orders is this Wendsday (05/08), which leaves us with several options: 1) We can order one of the two cameras on the assumption that one will be enough to keep us busy. On this front, I certainly lean toward the T265 based on its relevance to our overall objective: localization. 2) We can order both cameras because they fall under our 500$ limit, with the risk that we don't fully explore them. 3) We can elect to not order anything with the assumption that we will have enough things to do with the current hardware (Thinking back to the list of actionables proposed by Declan during the previous leadership meeting). On the topic of other hardware: the few that come to mind are the Jetson Nano, and the Google Coral dev board. We seem to have enough Jetsons in circulation through Dana and Mark, so I'm not amiable to ordering one. The Coal board is geared toward ML and Tensorflow, which has been debunked as unnecessary in the past. Thoughts / Opinions?

2019-05-05
Dana Batali7:37 AM

good analysis from my POV. I would lean toward 1 or 2 265s. If we adopt the 265 we'll need >= 2, but on the assumption that availability won't be an issue, we should hold off on the second until after we prove #1 works for us. As pointed out above, they raise concerns with crowds of moving things.

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:05 AM

Another thing to consider: You can get image data from the grayscale cameras on the T265. The documentation is a little hard to come by, but it seems like this is limited to 30 Hz. See https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/tree/master/examples/pose-and-image>

That would mean we could still try rolling our own solution with this camera.

I think I might take the chance to shoot an email off to Jeffrey's dad (Marshall) in the next 1-2 days with a couple of questions, including his opinion on the T265.

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:27 AM

Also, here are a couple of links to some interesting bits of information (in no particular order):
Odometry calibration format (you can adjust covariance and physical transform for the odometry data source here!): https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/blob/master/doc/t265.md#wheel-odometry-calibration-file-format>
Known issues. This indicates that it will be a hassle to save relocalization maps and send wheel odometry data. (On the bright side, relocalization maps are supported!): https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/blob/master/doc/t265.md#notes--known-issues/blob/9bdbfd98440b6516f8c864fbdfd6a9778b2c5715/doc/t265.md#notes--known-issues>
Informative thread on lots of stuff: https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/issues/3129>
Video about using D425 and T265 on wheeled robots (haven't got around to watching this one): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62vm0_RZ1nU>

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:39 AM

Hmm... That known issues bit might not be correct. They say you must use the underlying device driver, but it seems like this (https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/blob/bcc71f3b01c482dfa51895ab6247135c9c76323d/include/librealsense2/hpp/rssensor.hpp#L548>) would work just fine. This header file includes `sendwheelodometry` and `export/importrelocalizationmap`! (Another interesting bit is that `sendwheel_odmetry` only takes translational velocities, so no absolute position or angular vel).

Declan Freeman-Gleason7:11 PM

I spent a little time today working on making JNI bindings to the T265 RealSense API. They have some Java bindings themselves, but they're not complete. Everything for the T265 is undocumented, but it makes sense once you find the right header files to read. I didn't have much time so I haven't finished, but this gives you a taste for what the API looks like: https://github.com/Spartronics4915/SpartronicsLib/blob/master/src/main/java/com/spartronics4915/lib/sensors/native/t265wrapper.cpp>

The cool thing about offloading all the hard parts to an ASIC is that we can just plug into the RoboRIO and go.

Also, I compiled the RealSense SDK/librealsense for my system. It wasn't too hard and now I have some cool tools, but I can already see that cross-compiling for the RoboRIO will be a major hassle (there are a lot of dependencies).

Dana Batali9:51 AM

thumbs up on all this progress!

2019-05-11
Mark Tarlton6:22 PM

before I forget -- If we use picams next year, you may want to consider using longer ribbon cables so that the computer can be located down with the other electronics and only the camera module exposed. This should simplify mounting and wiring. For example, here's a 2M cable available from Amazon https://www.amazon.com/A1-FFCs-Raspberry-Camera-Length/dp/B07JB2Y65D/ref=sr17?keywords=raspberry+pi+camera+cable+2m&qid=1557623776&s=electronics&sr=1-7>

2019-05-31
Noah Solomon12:44 PM

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1KkREufmKQU8C6ncYTTnnSp2QiPkmFd/view?usp=drivesdk>

Noah Solomon12:45 PM

Made this with processing last meeting!!

Noah Solomon12:46 PM

Extremely simple, but kinda cool. It gets the mouse position, then chooses a random point within the canvas size and draws a line between the two, in a random RGB color.

Noah Solomon12:47 PM

void setup() {
size(1000, 1000);
}

void draw() {
if (mousePressed) {
fill(0);
} else {
fill(255);
}

float x1 = random(0,1000);
float y1 = random(0,1000);
float x2 = random(0,1000);
float y2 = random(0,1000);

float r = random(0,255);
float g = random(0,255);
float b = random(0,255);

strokeWeight(1);
stroke(r, g, b);
line(x1, y1, mouseX, mouseY);
}

Riyadth Al-Kazily3:27 PM

Processing is a cool IDE/development system. It makes graphics and such pretty easy to do. And you can connect it to the outside world with Arduino to make programs that interact with sensors and stuff:
https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/connecting-arduino-to-processing>

2019-06-21
Darwin Clark2:19 PM

Hey programmers, happy end of school! Now that we have much more time on our hands, we can spend more time on our summer projects(cc'ing everyone with a project: @Justice James@Ryan Olney@Jeffrey Tappen@Austin Smith@Declan Freeman-Gleason). A fantastic idea by @Binnur Alkazily was to provide weekly updates, to keep us all updated on where others are with their projects, and provide a discussion forum. Ideas for what to include in your weekly update: What you have accomplished thus far, any questions you have that other programmers could answer, what you plan to do in the future, or how you are liking your project. Remember: the best way to get better at something is to practice by doing! I'll go first:

Darwin Clark2:24 PM

This week I spent most of the the time on my project re-aquinting myself with the vision code. My short-term goal is to do a lot of refactoring to make summer vision testing go well. I took some notes on things that can be changed, and there is a lot of organisation that needs to happen. Primarily, 2019-specific code needs to be moved to a 2019-specific directory/locale. Long-term I want to research generating documentation for individual methods to make the codebase more sustainable!

2019-06-22
Declan Freeman-Gleason3:02 PM

Over the past month I have set up a new year-independent Spartronics library (see https://github.com/Spartronics4915/SpartronicsLib>). I wrote a hybrid "command state machine" library that is included here. I also made some improvements to the drivetrain code (still a WIP). I also wrote a JNI wrapper for the T265 tracking camera, and got everything (including librealsense) to cross-compile for the RoboRIO.

I am very close to testing the camera stuff on the robot. Later in the summer I plan to port path following to SpartronicsLib, and then I would like to work on LIDAR object identification.

2019-06-24
Dana Batali8:12 PM

https://github.com/cannerycoders/webcam>

Binnur Alkazily10:24 AM

For those that are interested in setting up github pages w/ jekyll — I recommend using the docker setup. It is nice change from dealing w/ messy ruby+gem dev environment. Past week, I decided to take this on and start migrating my wordpress blog to github (I hate the ad based revenue products!)
You can find the docker-compose.yml I used on the repo: https://github.com/binnur/binnur.github.io>

2019-06-29
Binnur Alkazily9:29 PM

Some great gems — my highlights:
- “Without requirements or design, programming is the art of adding bugs to an empty text file.”
- Future thinking is future trashing
- Documentation is a love letter to your future self
- One commit per change
- Think of the users
- You’re responsible for the use of your code — the difference between “freedom” and “responsibility”
- Post your stupid solution online
- Keep a list of “Things I Don’t Know” — I use this as my Feymann notebooks
https://blog.juliobiason.net/thoughts/things-i-learnt-the-hard-way/>
