2019-08-05
Darwin Clark8:52 PM

Status update on summer programming work thread: For the past ~3 weeks Declan and I have been meeting in his garage to work on robotics-related projects. We wanted to give a status update of where we are, and what the plan is going forward with summer meetings. Our last meeting for summer work is this Wednesday, at which point we will evaluate where we are and what we discovered. Due to availability issues that meeting will be the last meeting for summer work, but we hope to meet again with all who are interested the weekend of the 24th (@Binnur Alkazily is your house available for a meeting space?) as a debrief. In this thread we will give status updates of where we are. (@Declan Freeman-Gleason @Justice James)

Binnur Alkazily8:53 PM

Yup, that time frame works!

Darwin Clark9:02 PM

(Heads up: extra verbose. Be warned!) For vision, we are currently evaluating heading offset and height error as a method of tracking/driving to a target, and have some neat footage to share. I began summer work on vision with the goal of getting down the lower level and with a renewed focus of empirical testing. The first big hurdle was a bizzare bug with camera behaivor / state changing when a bright object was brought in close proximity. (Illistration here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1kT3YG50jpIM3zwPP1coGwGKq-zUNm0IY/view?usp=sharing>) After asking around on the FRC Discord, someone suggested changing the 'sensor_mode' to '7', as opposed to leaving it at 0, (auto sensor mode) and that solved the issue. After solving some math error in the 'rectUtil' libary, we were ready to go. (Declan will be posting a video of about where we got today) Moving forward, I plan to organise and prepare the repository for 2020, as well as do some rescrturing in 'algo' and 'rectUtil', with will hopefully make the libraries more portable from game to game. For the near future, I want to discuss as a group where we want to go with hardware. Both the Jetson Nano and Raspberry Pi 4 have made USB 3.0 commonplace, so perhaps a re-evaluation of CSI-cameras is warranted.

Declan Freeman-Gleason10:30 PM

Here's a video of the robot following a target based on its angle: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YhgLwssREzYq1RBQVuZkSOuNaHjE8p_b/view?usp=sharing>

I will post a robot keeping a constant distance and angle from the target soon.

2019-08-06
Declan Freeman-Gleason1:56 AM

I guess I'll also add my own progress and plans:

I spent about a week and a half testing the T265 in a variety of conditions, fixing some remaining graceful cleanup bugs, and submitting a PR to librealsense upstream. For the condition testing, I tried to perform controlled, duplicated trials. This convinced me that the camera is extremely dependent on consistent lighting conditions. If you lighting is good you can consistently have less than 2 inches of error. If you lighting is bad you can have up to 10 inches of error. I believe that the FRC field lighting conditions (at least for district events) will play nicely with the camera. I am a little concerned about the lighting during district championships, however.

The following week was spent on other parts of my life so I didn't really do much with robotics.

The last 4 days have involved porting all the path planning code to SpartronicsLib. I have significantly cleaned up and refactored the path code. I finished this today, and the new SpartronicsLib path planning code produces the same results (numerically) as 2019-DeepSpace's code. All units are meters now.

The next two weeks will involve on-robot testing of path planning, and writing LIDAR object identification code.

If everything goes well, the week after that will be work on planning a path around obstacles, and integrating the LIDAR, T265, and path planning work.

Paul Vibrans8:45 AM

Great work! I like the robot noise when it turns to the light, kind of like my dog when I move a toy away from his line of sight.

Dana Batali9:21 AM

great progress! Would love to see some optimization at this point: ie: the motion is jerky and discontinuous... Getting up the frame rate (as @Darwin Clark points out) and getting turn and approach working... The PID seems reasonably responsive (at least to "settle") and that's what's a little confusing to me: why the jerky motion? Seems to me it's all about getting going and so indeed cranking P might help (then you'll overshoot and need to crank D and I perhaps)

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: can you comment more on the term "object identification" wrt lidar? What do you have in mind?

Dana Batali9:32 AM

also on the "inner-loop" vision: would we need a "state machine" to go from "acquire target" to "pursue target", then back to acquire (if it's lost during pursuit)?

Declan Freeman-Gleason2:23 PM

Yeah, it was a little slow to respond because P was a little small. It should be easy to tune. I don't think we need a formal state machine in this case because vision already tracks state, so you can just do a `if (acquired) {} else {}`.

As for the LIDAR thing, I'm planning to make it identify shapes in the point cloud. There was a (Candadian?) team with a name I can't remember that used this to identify cubes in 2018. I was initially planning to use the Hough transform to detect arbitrary shapes specified parametrically, but I now believe that I will have to explore other options because the LIDAR won't be able to capture a 360 degree view of an object.

Dana Batali8:44 PM

hm - since it's a 2D point-cloud, the idea of shape must pertain to finding lines and corners.

on the acquired thing: we'd need some hysteresis so it doesn't jump back and forth between the two states.

Justice James10:51 PM

I've been working on two separate robotics-related projects over the summer - a rewrite of CHAOS's code to be command based, and a multiplatform scouting app to replace and extend AppSheet's functionality.

Rewriting CHAOS is mostly to reintegrate myself with the robot code, and get prepared for teaching new students this fall. I'd estimate that I'm over 2/3 of the way done - All commands and subsystems are done, and I'm in the process of finishing the buttonboard. My short-term goal is to finish this project before the end of the week.

The scouting app is much less of a priority, but I've still made some nice progress on it. Flutter took me a while to get set up, and I still haven't fixed an emulator bug I've been having. For now I've found a workaround. My first and biggest goal is to reimplement basic AppSheet functionality in a way such that someone new to the team could create questions easily. After that, I've been playing around with ideas to make this integrate with The Green Alliance and be usable for other teams, as well as add a way to easily view spreadsheet data.

Unfortunately, I can't make the meeting the weekend of the 24th, as I'll be in the Cascades for two weeks. Have a good debrief!

2019-08-07
Dana Batali8:12 AM

@Justice James: :+1:... question on command-based-rewrite... Do you have an opinion on whether this makes the code easier to understand or to write (compared to last year's approach)?? At our last status meeting, the notion was that moving back to commands might provide a more end-to-end experience... Does it? Can you point us at some examples?

Justice James9:44 PM

@Dana Batali I think it does! The command structure works out well to break down subsystems into less complicated actions calling a subsystem method. I found that many things we had found workarounds for in the old codebase are much more easily implemented and straightforward (the Climber comes to mind). The best example of how much commands help understanding code would probably be the CargoIntake subsystem. I'm all for using this on our 2020 robot.

Everything I've done has been being pushed to the command-base branch on 2019-DeepSpace, if anyone wants to check it out. It's currently missing autonomous actions and path planning, but those are next on my priority list.

2019-08-08
Dana Batali8:38 AM

@Declan Freeman-Gleason: can I assume that you've perused this and are also on board? Is it worth comparing and contrasting with the same solution but via 254's actions/modes? I ask this because debugging into the command-processing-engine might be more difficult than debugging into our own (in-repo) code.

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:41 AM

I’m onboard with the command thing. One important thing to note is that the command-based system has been rewritten for 2020. You can pull in the new version as a jitpack dependency and view it in isolation here: https://github.com/Oblarg/command-rewrite-jitpack>

The user facing bits do change a little.

Dana Batali8:48 AM

i haven't looked into this, but one thing that may be worth understanding is the reliance and or impact that this has on threads. If all the dispatching of commands happens in the main thread (which is my guess), this means we'll not suffer from the lock contention issue, but we might suffer from issues that arise when a command or subsystem consumes too much of a time-slice.

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:51 AM

I haven’t seen anything indicating a multithreaded design. I expect it would be too much of a footgun for rookies for wpilib to adopt.

I think policing subsystem runtimes is easier than reducing overuse/misuse of `synchronized` with the new programmers anyway.

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:02 PM

More demo videos incoming!

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:08 PM

Here's the robot going to a vision target (using the inner-loop vision method): https://drive.google.com/open?id=1VFTDIL7Jhue2vJZgL1VW2gzUDdcNWLuI>

Declan Freeman-Gleason8:08 PM

Here's the robot "following the leader": https://drive.google.com/open?id=1ypmJ1OzJYR5N6qFQisc2uWWDVFmmmt>

2019-08-09
Dana Batali12:57 PM

i sense the sweet smell of success! Great job guys!!

Are you using pixel-height of target for your distance measure?

Have you tried targeting something, say 4-6 feet off the ground?

Any sense of your frame-rate on the target updates?

Darwin Clark2:08 PM

Yep. In the code there is a 'wanted' height in pixels, which is used to create an offset value which is (normally) between 1.5 and 0 . We played around with several values for the wanted height, and found there is a maximum value, which is a function of the camera position on the robot. We also compared the computation time of 240p (10 ms) frames vs. 480p (~30 ms) frames, and found (interestingly) the computation time is only really tripled to run a frame that is four times bigger. Streaming the frame increases the computation time tenfold. (~120 ms) In general, fps was not a concern. Additionally, I came to the conclusion that the position of the camera on the robot is pretty critical from a FOV perspective. (@Mark Tarlton) I.E, the target could not be very high above the ground in our tests because of the vertical FOV.

Declan Freeman-Gleason6:12 PM

We also found that the camera is best mounted away from the edge of the robot, because there is a minimum distance that is hit when the target becomes larger than the FOV.

2019-08-10
Dana Batali12:42 PM

660 FPS!

https://hackaday.com/2019/08/10/660-fps-raspberry-pi-video-captures-the-moment-in-extreme-slo-mo/>

Paul Vibrans11:26 PM

So much to see in this video!!! Multi plane balancing. Why my lawnmower won't cut even with freshly sharpened blades. And more.
It reminds me of the good old days when I tried to use a record card from an FM tape recorder to get strain gauge data off a spinning propeller shaft. 12" diameter and 240 RPM was too much for the discrete electronics used in those days. I lost a few ferrite core inductors sometime during the test.

2019-08-11
Mark Tarlton10:25 AM

That's so cool!
Great work with the robot tracking! that's really encouraging.

It's not surprising that the camera needs to be mounted back away from the front of the robot. Just think of the view triangle and the size of the target, As it gets close, the target more than fills the image..
with the low camera position, I expect that most of the image is filled with floor..

also does your tracking still work when the target moves up and down relative to the central axis of the camera?

Darwin Clark11:29 AM

@Mark Tarlton The tracking demonstrated is independent of vertical position. The height is calculated by using the topmost corner of the left rectangle and the bottom-most corner of the same rectangle (if my memory serves me right). We didn't have much vertical space to test, but in theory it should still work when the target moves vertically, because the height offset and heading are not calculated using any vertical relativity to the frame (I.E a target near the top of the frame returns similar results to a target near the bottom of the frame if they share the same ' X ' value)

Terry Shields10:04 PM

I’m just catching up to your latest video post on the summer programming effort. Great work guys!!! The robot response time for tracking AND reacting to the target is very impressive.

Your proof of concept has me sold!

2019-08-17
Declan Freeman-Gleason4:49 PM

254 released their 2019 code. They reverted to their 2017 path planning with arcs and adaptive pure pursuit. The only change is that they use a motor model to calculate feedforward. They are also using the inner-loop vision method to go to targets (i.e. not PNP).

Overall the only really interesting-looking/innovative thing is their arm/wrist motion planning and constraints.

https://github.com/Team254/FRC-2019-Public>

2019-08-18
Dana Batali11:26 AM

nice! now we'll not be tempted to throw out last year's (and this summer's) work! Interesting that they bailed on the spline and other path following controllers.

At some point I would like to brainstorm on characterizing/optimizing inner-loop vision.

And indeed the wrist+arm control problem is interesting (and more complex than one might imagine)

Declan Freeman-Gleason12:19 PM

Their code has a good example of inner-loop vision in Drive.

From what I’ve heard they experienced a bit of programming brain-drain and that was why they bailed on the new system.

Microsoft has a new Kinect device . It has a 1Mpixel depth camera and a 12Mpixel RGB video camera plus an IMU. It's a USB3 device and much smaller than the older kinects. $360 edu price.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/kinect-dk/>

Declan Freeman-Gleason11:13 PM

@Dana Batali @Binnur Alkazily @Riyadth Al-Kazily @Darwin Clark As promised, a video of the robot playing tag using the LIDAR sensor to find the ball, and the T265 camera for getting there and back: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1L2akjVghu6RRCkI79oqtxuNRlOt-aN8t/view?usp=drivesdk>

2019-08-28
Dana Batali9:38 AM

as a level-2 challenge, how bout putting the ball off-axis so more turning is required.

Other questions:
1. is the wheel odometry fused?
2. when you say the camera gets you there and back do you mean: "we used the camera's inter-frame estimation as the source of odometry and then used our path planner to navigate from point a to b then back to a"
3. this suggests that LIDAR is used in a "one-shot mode", right? If so, did you compare it against an inner-loop mode?

You can always tell when a milestone is a significant one when you out-of-nowhere can see a whole bunch of additional milestones further down the road. Great work!

Declan Freeman-Gleason9:46 AM

I have tried this with the ball more off-axis, and it works fine.

1. Wheel odometry is being fused, not that I can tell any difference.
2. Yes, we used the camera’s pose estimation as a source of odometry for the path planner (and to correct pointcloud motion smear).
3. Yes, LIDAR was running in a one-shot mode. I didn’t compare to an inner loop mode. One shot mode gave very good results when the ball was in range.

Binnur Alkazily11:14 AM

Nice job! As Dana mentioned, you can take this demo up a notch w/ small tweaks: place the ball off axis, and stop (vs drift) when contact is made. I look forward to seeing the action in person!

2019-08-30
Declan Freeman-Gleason7:03 PM

@Darwin Clark @Dana Batali This looks interesting: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/introducing-chameleon-vision/362061>

There’s no hardware tight coupling, source, or PNP though so it’s probably not a viable choice for us.

2019-09-02
Declan Freeman-Gleason7:38 PM

@Binnur Alkazily @Dana Batali @Darwin Clark @Riyadth Al-Kazily Further work with the T265 has shown that wheel odometry does in fact do something, and that I am sending good data to the sensor. If I am sending wheel odometry and cover the T265 with my hand and move the robot then the pose will change normally and accurately. If I am not sending odometry then the pose will not change when the T265 is covered and the robot is moving. Accuracy doesn't change if you send odometry though, so it appears that odometry only really helps if data from the cameras is unusable (e.g. the scene is occluded from the viewpoint of the camera because a robot is in front of us, or there's a lot of vibration).

More investigation has further cemented my view that lighting is the thing that influences accuracy the most. I have posted this (https://github.com/IntelRealSense/librealsense/issues/4789>) issue to the librealsense GitHub to try to get some support regarding our lighting difficulties. Pictures are included.

2019-09-03
Dana Batali9:31 AM

Impressive! Nicely put-together customer-support query. Working with a real-world vendor and sharing well-reasoned problems with them is bound to bear tasty fruit!

2019-11-10
Paul Vibrans9:47 PM

Don't be sucked in by indefinite comparatives and ad speak!!! The data I have now for both motors indicate NEO's are better than Falcon 500's below 28.4 A input current (DC) with 12 volt input. At some points, like 15 A, the NEO is as much as 8.5% more efficient. The Falcon 500 appears to be designed to run at 60 A normally whereas the NEO is designed to run at 30 A normally. Both motors are better than CIM's.

The time constants on the 40A circuit breakers are large enough to allow continuous operation for about one minute at 60A without tripping. If we intend to do this on a regular basis, we should swap breakers between matches so we do not start a match with a hot breaker that has consumed some of its time constant.

The problem I see with both motors is the inability to test their installation mechanics with simple devices such as an old 12V battery and a switch.

We should buy one of these motors and connect it to a gearbox that drives a large eccentric weight that loads the motor to 40A. We should run the motor for a couple of hours to see how it holds up to the +/- high torque cyclic loading. We will learn if the controller has 4 quadrant capability if the battery can stand the testing.

2019-11-11
Carter Anderson12:25 PM

@Carter Anderson has joined the channel

Binnur Alkazily9:17 PM

http://www.pearlleff.com/seven-tips-for-a-junior-developer>

2019-11-12
Henry Tuohy9:04 AM

@Henry Tuohy has joined the channel

Dana Batali9:52 AM

All good points. As an aside, from a programming and electrical point of view, it's very nice to have a single PKG with encoder, controller and motor. Moreover, our existing can-talon srx software is purported to just work. This doesn't appear to be the case with neos. As for test rigs, this one might/should be drivable from a STD pwm rig

Paul Vibrans11:51 AM

I re-read the Falcon 500 motor manual and inferred that the reverse polarity protection is a product of the inverter configuration. You can't ignore the DC input polarity, you just can't wreck it with the wrong polarity. This had me worried that there was an energy sapping diode bridge upstream of everything that we needed to worry about. The PWM test rig is clearly needed; do we have one?

Dana Batali12:36 PM

need to check with @Riyadth Al-Kazily… but I think the answer is yes

Riyadth Al-Kazily12:38 PM

Yes, we have at least 3 or 4 PWM motor testers, and I can fabricate more if needed.

2019-11-14
Binnur Alkazily8:56 PM

2019-11-18
Declan Freeman-Gleason10:50 AM

@Camden Greenhalgh Here are the things you should try with the LIDAR on Wednesday:

1. Get the LIDAR preview running by cloning https://github.com/Spartronics4915/SpartronicsLib>, connecting the sensor via USB, and running `./gradlew test --tests interactivePointcloudTest --rerun-tasks`. It looked like this threw an exception on your computer. If it still does, find where and why that exception is being thrown, and fix it.
2. I will provide a yoga ball. See if you can hold the yoga ball to the LIDAR and in order to get it to track.
3. (This is the big task) Make a new class called `TargetTracker` that has an `update` method that takes a list of `Pose2d`s. These `Pose2d`s can come from `ObjectFinder` (note that `ObjectFinder` returns `Pose2d`s in order of the number of "votes" that each `Pose2d`; i.e. the best objects found are first in the list), and you want to find the "best" object over multiple updates. That means you need to correlate objects across updates, and find the one that is both the oldest and is highest ranked most consistently.

2019-11-20
Binnur Alkazily4:02 PM

@Maya Shaw as we discussed at the last meeting, this evening I’d like you to complete your system setup for Bling Demo project. As you go through the instructions, also keep track of what should be improved/added for documentation. I included code experiments to try out as well. See documentation:
https://github.com/Spartronics4915/developershandbook/blob/master/arduinobling/bling.md>

Declan Freeman-Gleason5:58 PM

@Austin Smith @Noah Solomon @Henry Hays I'm going to be gone for the first half hour of the meeting. You should try to get your computers set up.

1. First, make sure that you are connected to ethernet.
2. Then, follow this installation guide: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/latest/docs/getting-started/getting-started-frc-control-system/wpilib-setup.html>.
3. Clone https://github.com/pietroglyph/example_robot> and try to deploy it with `./gradlew deploy` to the test chassis.
